   Adopting Ordinance




   AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING A CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR THE VILLAGE OF CHANNAHON
REVISING, AMENDING, RESTATING, CODIFYING AND COMPILING CERTAIN EXISTING
GENERAL ORDINANCES OF THE VILLAGE DEALING WITH SUBJECTS EMBRACED IN THE CODE




   WHEREAS, the Village of Channahon is a Home Rule Municipality under and
by virtue of the Constitution of the State of Illinois; and



   WHEREAS, the Acts of the State Legislature of the State of Illinois
empower and authorize the Corporate Authority of the Village to revise,
amend, restate, codify and to compile any existing ordinance or ordinances
and all new ordinances not heretofore adopted or published and to incorporate
such ordinances into one ordinance in book form; and



   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authority of the Village of Channahon has
authorized a general compilation, revision and codification of the ordinances
of the village of a general and permanent nature and publication of such
ordinances in book form.



   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
OF THE VILLAGE OF CHANNAHON, WILL COUNTY, ILLINOIS, IN THE EXERCISE OF THEIR
HOME RULE AND OTHER POWERS:



Section 1:   That the general ordinances of the Village of Channahon as
herein revised; amended, restated, codified and compiled in book form are
adopted as and shall constitute the "Code of Ordinances" of the Village of
Channahon.



Section 2:   That the Code as adopted in Section 1 shall consist of the
following titles, to-wit:



         Title 1      General Provisions



         Title 111   Administration



         Title V      Public Works



         Title VII   Traffic Code



         Title IX   General Regulations



         Title XI   Business Regulations



         Title XIlI   General Offenses



         Title XV   Land Usage



         Tables of Special Ordinances



         Parallel References



         Index



         and such other titles as from time to time be adopted.



Section 3:   That all ordinances prior to ordinance number 840 pertaining
to the subjects treated in the Code which are inconsistent with the Code
shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of the Code except
as they are included and reordained in whole or in part in the Code; provided
such repeal shall not affect any offense committed or penalty incurred or any
right established prior to the effective date of the Code, or shall such
repeal affect the provisions of ordinances levying taxes, appropriating
money, annexing or detaching territory establishing franchises or granting
special rights to certain persons, authorizing public improvements,
authorizing the issuance of bonds or borrowing of money, authorizing the
purchase or sale of real or personal property, granting or accepting
easements, plat or dedication of land to public use, naming or vacating or
setting the boundaries of streets, alleys or other public places, nor to any
other ordinance of a temporary or special nature or pertaining to subjects
not contained therein.



Section 4:   That the Clerk of the Village of Channahon is hereby
authorized and ordered to file a copy of the Code in the Office of the
Village Clerk.



Section 5:   That the Code shall be in full force and effect from and
after its passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form and filing
thereof in the Office of the Clerk, and the Code shall be presumptive
evidence in all courts and places of the ordinances and all provisions,
sections, penalties and regulations therein contained and of the date of
passage, and that the same is properly signed, attested, recorded and
approved and that any public hearings and notices thereof as required by law
have been given.



   PASSED, ATTESTED and APPROVED this 6th day of November, 1995.



Wayne W. Chesson  /s/



Village President



Christine Pucel  /s/



Village Clerk

§ 10.01  TITLE OF CODE.



   This codification of ordinances by and for the Village of Channahon,
shall be designated as the Code of Channahon, Illinois, and may be so cited.



§ 10.02  INTERPRETATION.



   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required,
the same rules of construction, definition, and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of state
law.



§ 10.03  APPLICATION TO FUTURE ORDINANCES.



   All provisions of Title I compatible with future legislation, shall
apply to ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this code
unless otherwise specifically provided.



§ 10.04  CAPTIONS.



   Headings and captions used in this code other than the title, chapter,
and section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be
deemed a part of the text of any section.



§ 10.05  DEFINITIONS.



   (A)   General rule.  Words and phrases shall be taken in their
plain, or ordinary and usual sense.  However, technical words and phrases
having a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood
according to their technical import.



   (B)   For the purpose of this code, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CITY, MUNICIPAL CORPORATION, MUNICIPALITY, or TOWN.  The Village of
Channahon, Illinois.



   CODE,THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES.  This municipal code as
modified by amendment, revision, and adoption of new titles, chapters, or
sections.



   CORPORATE AUTHORITIES.  The President and Board of Trustees of the
village.



   COUNTY.  Will County, Illinois.



   MAY.  The act referred to is permissive.



   MONTH.  A calendar month.



   OATH.  An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation
may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words SWEAR and SWORN
shall be equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED.



   OFFICER, OFFICE, EMPLOYEE, COMMISSION, or DEPARTMENT.  An officer,
office, employee, commission, or department of this municipality unless the
context clearly requires otherwise.



   PERSON.  Extends to and includes person, persons, firm, corporation,
copartnership, trustee, lessee, or receiver.  Whenever used in any clause
prescribing and imposing a penalty, the terms PERSON or WHOEVER as applied to
any unincorporated entity shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as
applied to corporations, the officers or agents thereof.



   PRECEDING or FOLLOWING.  Next before or next after, respectively.



   SHALL.  The act referred to is mandatory.



   SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION.  Includes a mark when the person cannot
write.



   STATE.  The State of Illinois.



   SUBCHAPTER.  A division of a chapter, designated in this code by a
heading in the chapter analysis and a capitalized heading in the body of the
chapter, setting apart a group of sections related by the subject matter of
the heading.  Not all chapters have subchapters.



   WRITTEN.  Any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by
printing or otherwise.



   YEAR.  A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed; equivalent to the
words YEAR OF OUR LORD.



§ 10.06  RULES OF INTERPRETATION.



   The construction of all ordinances of this municipality shall be by the
following rules, unless such construction is plainly repugnant to the intent
of the legislative body or of the context of the same ordinance:



   (A)    AND or.  Either conjunction shall include the other as if
written "and/or," if the sense requires it.



   (B)   Acts by assistants.  When a statute or ordinance  requires 
an  act  to be done which, by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the
principal, such requisition shall be satisfied by the performance of such act
by an authorized agent or deputy.



   (C)   Gender; singular and plural; tenses.  Words denoting the
masculine gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders;
words in the singular shall include the plural, and words in the plural shall
include the singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include
the future, if applicable.



   (D)   General term.  A general term following specific enumeration
of terms is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so
limited.



§ 10.07  SEVERABILITY.



   If any provision of this code as now or later amended or its
application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity
does not affect other provisions that can be given effect without the invalid
provision or application.



§ 10.08  REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.



   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof,
such reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as
subsequently amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject
matter is changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.



§ 10.09  REFERENCE TO OFFICES.



   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer, or employee of this municipality exercising the powers,
duties, or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any
transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary.



§ 10.10  ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.



   If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any
words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention
of the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning
can be attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was
clearly intended to  express such  intent, such spelling shall be corrected
and such word or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with
the manifest intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as
though the correct words were contained in the text as originally
published.  No alteration shall be made or permitted if any question exists
regarding the nature or extent of such error.



§ 10.11  OFFICIAL TIME.



   The official time, as established by applicable state/federal laws,
shall be the official time within this municipality for the transaction of
all municipal business.



§ 10.12  REASONABLE TIME.



   (A)   In all cases where an ordinance requires an act to be done in
a reasonable time or requires reasonable notice to be given, reasonable time
or notice shall be deemed to mean the time which is necessary for a prompt
performance of such act or the giving of such notice.



   (B)   The time within which an act is to be done, as herein
provided, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the
last.  If the last day be Sunday, it shall be excluded.



§ 10.13  [RESERVED].



§ 10.14  ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.



   All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other
ordinances pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in
full force and effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary
implication.



§ 10.15  EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES.



   All  ordinances  passed  by  the  legislative  body requiring
publication shall take effect from and after the due publication thereof,
unless otherwise expressly provided.  Ordinances not requiring publication
shall take effect from their passage, unless otherwise expressly provided.



§ 10.16  REPEAL OR MODIFICATION OF ORDINANCE.



   (A)   Whenever any ordinance or part of an ordinance shall be
repealed or modified by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of an
ordinance thus repealed or modified shall continue in force until the due
publication of the ordinance repealing or modifying it when publication is
required to give effect thereto, unless otherwise expressly provided.



   (B)   No suit, proceedings, right, fine, forfeiture, or penalty
instituted, created, given, secured, or accrued under any ordinance previous
to its repeal shall in anyway be affected, released, or discharged, but may
be prosecuted, enjoyed, and recovered as fully as if the ordinance had
continued in force unless it is otherwise expressly provided.



   (C)   When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause, or
provision shall by itself repealed, the repeal shall not be construed to
revive the former ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it is expressly
provided.



§ 10.17  ORDINANCES WHICH AMEND OR SUPPLEMENT CODE.



   (A)   If the legislative body shall desire to amend any existing
chapter or section of this code, the chapter or section shall be specifically
repealed and a new chapter or section, containing the desired amendment,
substituted in its place.



   (B)   Any ordinance which is proposed to add to the existing code a
new chapter or section shall indicate, with reference to the arrangement of
this code, the proper number of such chapter or section.  In addition to
such indication thereof as may appear in the text of the proposed ordinance,
a caption or title shall be shown in concise form above the ordinance.



§ 10.18  SECTION HISTORIES; STATUTORY REFERENCES.



   (A)     As histories for the code sections, the specific number and
passage date of the original ordinance, and the most recent three amending
ordinances, if any, are listed following the text of the code section. 
Example:  (Ord. 10, passed 5-13-60; Am. Ord. 15, passed 1-1-70; Am. Ord. 20,
passed 1-1-80; Am. Ord. 25, passed 1-1-85)



   (B)   (1)     If a statutory cite is included in the history,
this indicates that the text of the section reads substantially the same as
the statute.  Example:  (ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5 § 3-2-7)  (Ord. 10, passed
1-17-80; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-85)



      (2)     If a statutory cite is set forth as a "statutory
reference" following the text of the section, this indicates that the reader
should refer to that statute for further information.



Example:



   § 31.10  MAYOR.



      The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the legislative body.



   (Ord. 10, passed 1-1-80)



   Statutory reference: For term of the Mayor, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5 §
3-4-4



§ 10.19  CORPORATE SEAL.



   The corporate seal shall be the seal heretofore provided and used by
and for the village, the impression of which is circular in form with words
"Corporate Seal" in the center thereof and with the inscription "Village of
Channahon, Illinois" in the outer circle thereof.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 10.98  COMPLIANCE TICKETS.



   The ordinances of the village are hereby amended to provide for the use
of compliance tickets for all ordinance violations except those that, in
accordance with ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 6-204, as it may from time to time be
amended, must be reported to the Secretary of State.



   (A)   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, any
person accused of violating any provision of this Code or any other ordinance
or regulation of the village may be issued a compliance ticket which shall
require the violator to:



      (1)   Pay an administrative fee as stated in division (F) of
this section to the Village Treasurer within 14 days of the issuance of a
compliance ticket as a settlement and compromise of the claim against the
violator. In the event payment of the administrative fee and compliance has
not been obtained within the 14-day period, the administrative fee will be
doubled for the period beginning the 15th day and including the 30th day
after issuance of the ticket. The offender shall have until the close of
business on the 30th day to satisfy the claim; and



      (2)   Correct, repair, or rectify any condition which
constitutes a continuing violation of a village ordinance or regulation
within the period specified in the compliance ticket.



   (B)   A compliance ticket may be issued as a courtesy to the
violator in lieu of instituting a prosecution for the alleged violation. If
the person accused of the violation fails to settle and pay the claim within
the period specified in the compliance ticket, the compliance ticket shall be
converted to a complaint or uniform traffic citation, and that person shall
be subject to prosecution in the Circuit Court and shall be subject to the
fines and penalties authorized by law or ordinance.



   (C)   If any person to whom a compliance ticket has been issued
desires to contest the validity of the compliance ticket, then that person
shall file a written notice within five days of the issuance of the
compliance ticket. The Village Administrator shall appoint a person to serve
as a hearing officer who shall, after receiving evidence from the person
issuing the compliance ticket and the person to whom the compliance ticket is
issued, render a decision.  If the person to whom the compliance ticket is
issued does not comply with any order issued by the hearing officer within
seven days, then the village shall have the right to pursue any available
remedy to seek collection and compliance, including prosecution in Circuit
Court.



   (D)   The Village Administrator is authorized to promulgate
administrative regulations to implement the compliance ticket programs.



   (E)   If a compliance ticket requires the correction or repair of a
condition within a period of time and the violator fails to correct, repair,
or rectify the violation within that period, then the village may issue
additional compliance tickets or may pursue prosecution in Circuit.



   (F)   (1)   Any person violating any provisions of the Village
Code is subject to the following administrative fees:



 



Improper disposal of garbage (Ch. 50)
 

$100

      (2)   A separate administrative fee shall accrue for each day
on which an offense continues.



(Ord. 827, passed 12-5-94; Am. Ord. 1496, passed 8-6-07; Am. Ord. 1611,
passed 3-15-10; Am. Ord. 1870, passed 10-3-16)



§ 10.99  GENERAL PENALTY.



   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this
code for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine not exceeding $500.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed upon each day during which a violation occurs or
continues.

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 30.01  COMPOSITION OF BOARD OF TRUSTEES; DUTIES.



   The Board of Trustees shall consist of the President and six trustees
elected for a four-year term.  Three members shall be elected every two
years.  The Board of Trustees is the legislative body of the village and is
the repository of all municipal powers which have not been specifically
delegated to some other office, commission, committee or board.  The
appointment of all officers, commissions, committees and boards shall be
subject to the approval of the Board of Trustees and the hiring and dismissal
of all employees of the village shall also be subject to approval of the
Board of Trustees.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 30.02  COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Each of the Village Trustees shall receive compensation of
$250 for each regular, special and committee meeting attended.



   (B)   In addition to the compensation herein provided, Trustees
shall be entitled to receive reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred
or advanced on behalf of the village.



(Ord. 892, passed 2-5-96; Am. Ord. 997, passed 9-21-98; Am. Ord. 1145, passed
9-18-00; Am. Ord. 1887, passed 3-6-17)



MEETINGS



§ 30.10  REGULAR MEETINGS.



   The regular meetings of the Corporate Authorities, to include dates,
times and places shall be announced, posted and advertised at the beginning
of each calendar year.  Any change to the regular schedule must be
announced, posted and advertised as required by law.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 30.11  SPECIAL MEETINGS; NOTICE.



   (A)   Special meetings may be called by the President or any three
Trustees upon a 24-hour notice to every member of the Board of Trustees;
provided that the requirement of a notice shall not be binding in any special
meeting at which all of the members of the Board of Trustees are present as
is provided by statute.



   (B)   Such notice may be served by any member of the Police
Department or by any other person in the village; and it shall be the duty of
the Village Clerk when given copies of such notices to serve the same or to
cause the same to be served immediately.



(Ord. 1, passed 5-14-62)



§ 30.12  QUORUM.



   A quorum for the transaction of business shall consist of a majority of
the Corporate Authorities.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 30.13  ADDRESSING CORPORATE AUTHORITIES.



   All persons desiring to address the Corporate Authorities or to present
petitions or communications requiring action at a regular meeting shall file
notice thereof with the Village Clerk not less than seven days prior to the
meeting.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 30.14  ORDER OF BUSINESS.



   The order of business shall be as follows:



   (A)   Call to order by presiding officer;



   (B)   Pledge of allegiance to the Flag;



   (C)   Roll call;



   (D)   Establishment of quorum;



   (E)   The reading and approval (with corrections and additions, if
any) of the journal of the proceedings of the previous meeting or meetings;



   (F)   Reports and communications from the Village President and
other officers:



      (1)   Treasurer (if required by a majority of the Corporate
Authorities);



      (2)   Attorney;



      (3)   Engineer;



      (4)   Board of Appeals;



      (5)   Planning and Zoning Commission;



      (6)   Building Commissioner;



      (7)   Village Clerk;



   (G)   Petitions, communications, orders, resolutions, and ordinances;



   (H)   Public discussion and comments from the floor;



   (I)   Unfinished business;



   (J)   Reports of special committees;



   (K)   Reports of standing committees:



      (1)   Accounts and Finances;



      (2)   Public Safety;



      (3)   Public Property;



      (4)   Public Affairs;



      (5)   Roads and Drainage;



      (6)   Public Health;



   (L)   Adjournment.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 30.15  PRESIDING OFFICER.



   The presiding officer (Village President or President Pro Tem) shall
preserve order and decorum and may speak to points of order in preference to
other members, and shall decide all questions of order subject to appeal. 
If he refuses to allow the Trustees to exercise their right of appeal a
decision of the Chair, the Board of Trustees may consider, and by majority
vote of its presence, may pass upon the matter in spite of the Chair's
failure to grant them an appeal.  In case of any disturbances or disorderly
conduct, the presiding officer shall have the power to require the chamber to
be cleared.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 30.16  ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER TO GOVERN.



   The current edition of Robert's Rules of Order, except when otherwise
provided by law or other provisions of this chapter, shall govern on all
questions or parliamentary procedure at said meetings.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 30.17  ALTERATION OF RULES.



   The rules may be altered, amended or temporarily suspended at any time
by resolution or ordinance passed by the Corporate Authorities.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 30.18  DISTURBING MEETING UNLAWFUL.



   It shall be unlawful to disturb or interrupt any regular or special
meeting of the Village Board.  Any person violating any provision of this
section shall be fined as provided in § 30.99, and may be summarily ejected
from the meeting room.



(Ord. 1, passed 5-14-62)  Penalty, see § 30.99



§ 30.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating the provisions of § 30.18 shall be fined not less
than $1 and not more than $10 for each offense.



(Ord. 1, passed 5-14-62)

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 31.01  APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS.



   The provisions in this chapter shall apply to all officers and
employees of the village, regardless of the time of creation of office,
appointment or employment thereof.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.02  RECORDS.



   All records kept by any officer or employee in connection with his work
are the property of the village and shall be subject to inspection by any
member of the Corporate Authorities at any time.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.03  RECEIPT OF MONEY.



   All monies received by any officer or employee on behalf of the village
shall be turned over to the Village Clerk with statement showing source of
same.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.04  CONSERVATORS OF PEACE; POWERS OF ARREST.



   The members of the Corporate Authorities, Village Clerk and all members
of the Police Department are hereby declared conservators of the peace with
such powers of arrest as are given conservators of the peace by statute.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.05  DUTY UPON TERMINATION OF OFFICE.



   Every officer or employee, upon termination of his office or position
for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver all books, records and other papers
and things relative to his office or position to the Village Clerk.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.06  OATH.



   Every officer of the village shall, before entering upon the duties of
his office, take the oath of office as prescribed by the statute at a public
meeting of the Corporate Authorities.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.07  BONDS; APPROVAL.



   (A)   Every officer, and every employee when directed by the
Corporate Authorities or by law, shall, before entering upon his duties of
office or position, execute a bond in such amount as may be determined by the
Corporate Authorities or by law, with sureties as it may approve, conditioned
upon the faithful performance of the duties of his office or position.  The
village will pay the premiums of said bonds. 



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



   (B)   All bonds required by law or ordinance to be submitted to and
approved by the Corporate Authorities shall first be submitted to the Village
Attorney and it shall be his duty to examine said bonds.  If in his judgment
the bonds are properly drawn and are legal and binding obligations, he shall
endorse the same with his approval.  If they are not, he shall endorse his
disapproval thereon together with his reasons therefor. 



(Ord. 217, passed 5-21-79)



§ 31.08  BONDS FOR OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL OTHER THAN THOSE SPECIFICALLY
LISTED.



   Prior to the entering upon the duties of Village Trustee, Chief of
Police, police officer, positions on the Planning and Zoning Commission and
employment in the Street Department and Maintenance Department, all such
persons shall execute a bond with security to be approved by the Corporate
Authorities made payable to the village in amounts of not less than $3,000
per person.  The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of
the duties of each office or position and the payment of all money received
by each officer or person according to the laws of the state and the
ordinances of the village.  The obligation of the sureties shall not extend
to any loss sustained by the insolvency, failure or closing of any bank
organized and existing either under the laws of the state or the United
States wherein the person has placed funds in his custody, providing the bank
has been approved by the Corporate Authorities as a depositary for said
funds.  This bond shall be a part of the blanket bond of the village.  The
village shall pay all premiums of said bond.  The bond shall be filed with
the Village Clerk.



(Ord. 217, passed 5-21-79)



§ 31.09  SALARIES.



   All officers and employees of the village shall receive such salary as
is provided for from time to time by law or ordinance.  No officer of
employee receiving a salary from the village shall be entitled to retain any
fees, or portion thereof, collected by him in the performance of his duties.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.10  JOB DESCRIPTION.



   A job description of all employee positions shall be on file with the
Village Clerk.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.11  APPOINTMENT OF OTHER OFFICERS.



   The Village President may, with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees, appoint such other officers as may be required or necessary under
the laws of the state or as the Corporate Authorities may deem to be
appropriate from time to time.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.12  REMOVAL FROM OFFICE.



   The Village President may remove any officer appointed by him pursuant
to this chapter in the manner provided by law.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.13  [RESERVED].



§ 31.14  DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN.



   (A)   The village hereby establishes the deferred compensation plan
(the "plan") in the form of the ICMA Retirement Corporation Deferred
Compensation Plan and Trust, referred to as Appendix A, attached to Ordinance
No. 1426, passed May 1, 2006.



   (B)   The assets of the plan shall be held in trust with the village
serving as trustee, for the exclusive benefit of the plan participants and
their beneficiaries, and the assets shall not be diverted to any other
purpose.



   (C)   The plan will permit loans.



   (D)   The village hereby executes the Declaration of Trust of the
ICMA Retirement Trust, attached to Ordinance No. 1426, passed May 1, 2006 as
Appendix B, intending this execution to be operative with respect to any
retirement or deferred compensation plan subsequently established by the
village if the assets of the plan are to be invested in the ICMA Retirement
Trust.



   (E)   The village hereby agrees to serve as trustee under the plan
and to invest funds held under the plan in the ICMA Retirement Trust.



   (F)   The Village Treasurer shall be the coordinator for this plan;
shall receive necessary reports, notices, etc., from the ICMA Retirement
Corporation or the ICMA Retirement Trust; shall cast on behalf of the village
any required votes under the ICMA Retirement Trust, administrative duties to
carry out the plan may be assigned to the appropriate departments, and is
authorized to execute all necessary agreements with the ICMA Retirement
Corporation incidental to the administration of the plan.



(Ord. 1426, passed 5-1-06)



§ 31.15  ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS.



   The Village President and Board of Trustees hereby adopt the Rules
Governing Electronic Attendance at Meetings, attached to Ordinance 1475,
passed March 19, 2007 as Exhibit "A", to permit any member of a public body
of the village to attend any meeting of said public body via electronic means.



(Ord. 1475, passed 3-19-07)



VILLAGE PRESIDENT



§ 31.20  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.



   The Village President shall be elected for a four-year term and is the
Chief Executive Officer of the village.  He shall perform all of the duties
which are prescribed by law and municipal ordinances, and he is required to
see that said laws and ordinances are faithfully executed.  He shall keep
the Board of Trustees informed on matters pertaining to the public affairs of
the village.  No action by the Village President shall be effective to bind
the village unless approved by the Corporate Authorities where required by
law.  The Village President shall appoint, with the advice and consent of
the Board of Trustees, such other officers, standing committees, commissions
and boards as prescribed by law and municipal ordinances that may be
necessary to the health, welfare and safety of the village.  The President
and Board of Trustees, voting together shall elect one member of the Board of
Trustees to the position of President Pro Tem.  The Trustee so elected
President Pro Tem shall serve as President when circumstances arise which, in
accordance with the provisions of the Illinois Revised Statutes, would so
necessitate.  The President and Board of Trustees may at any time, for any
reason whatever, remove said President Pro Tem and elect another member of
the Board of Trustees to said position.  The election to the position of
President Pro Tem shall take place following each public election.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.21  COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The President of the Village shall receive as compensation
$250 for each regular, special and committee meeting attended.



   (B)   The President shall receive additional compensation of $600 a
month for maintaining office hours in the Municipal Building on average of
two hours per week on a monthly basis.



   (C)   The President shall also receive a salary for the duties as
Liquor Control Commissioner in the sum of $720 annually and $120 per liquor
related meeting attended.



   (D)   In addition to the compensation herein provided, the President
shall be entitled to receive reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred
or advanced on behalf of the village.



(Ord. 157, passed 6-7-76; Am. Ord. 310, passed 2-7-83; Am. Ord. 593, passed
6-4-90; Am. Ord. 997, passed 9-21-98; Am. Ord. 1145, passed 9-18-00; Am. Ord.
1887, passed 3-6-17)



§ 31.22  BOND.



   Prior to entering upon the duties of the office of President of the
village, the President shall execute a bond with security to be approved by
the Corporate Authorities made payable to the village in an amount of not
less than $3,000.  The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful
performance of the duties of the office of President and the payment of all
money received by the President according to the laws of the state and the
ordinances of the village.  The obligation of the sureties shall not extend
to any loss sustained by the insolvency, failure or closing of any bank
organized or existing either under the laws of the state or the United States
wherein the President has placed funds in his custody, provided the bank has
been approved by the Corporate Authorities as a depositary for said funds. 
This bond may be part of the blanket bond of the village.  The village shall
pay all premiums of said bond.  The bond shall be filed with the Village
Clerk.



(Ord. 217, passed 5-21-79)



CLERK; DEPUTY CLERK



§ 31.30  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.



   The Village Clerk shall be elected to a four-year term to run
concurrently with that of the Village President.  The  Village  Clerk
shall attend all meetings of the Corporate Authorities and shall be the clerk
thereof, and shall keep a full and complete record of its proceedings, in the
journal.  The Village Clerk shall seal and attest all contracts and
ordinances of the village and all licenses, permits and other documents
requiring such formality.  The Village Clerk shall be the Village Collector
and shall keep accounts showing all monies received, the source and
disposition of same, and all other accounts and reports required by ordinance
or statute; shall forthwith turn over all money received for or on behalf of
the village, to  the  Village  Treasurer  with  a  statement  of  the
source thereof.  The Village Clerk shall publish, when required by law, and
keep a record of all ordinances and other documents which are required to be
kept and preserved by statute, and shall also keep a register or record of
all licenses or permits issued and payments therefor, a record of all
officers and employees of the village, and all other such records as may be
required by order of the Corporate Authorities or by ordinance or by
statute.  The Village Clerk shall be custodian of the official village seal
and shall also be custodian of all documents not otherwise assigned to
another office.  The Village Clerk shall properly index all documents and
records in custody for easy access and use thereof and shall perform such
other duties and services from time to time as may be required by the
statute, ordinance or order of the Corporate Authorities.  The Village Clerk
may delegate such of the foregoing duties above as may be delegated by law.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 31.31  BOND OF CLERK AND DEPUTY CLERK.



   (A)   Prior to entering upon the duties of the office of Clerk of
the village, the Clerk shall execute a bond with security to be approved by
the Corporate Authorities made payable to the village in the amount of
$20,000.  The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties of the office of Clerk and the payment of all money received by the
Clerk according to the laws of the state and the ordinances of the village. 
The obligation of the sureties shall not extend to any loss sustained by the
insolvency, failure or closing of any bank organized and existing either
under the laws of the state or the United States wherein the Clerk has placed
funds in his custody, provided the bank has been approved by the Corporate
Authorities as a depositary for said funds.  The village shall pay all
premiums of said bond.  The bond shall be filed with the Village Treasurer.



   (B)   Prior to the entering upon the duties of the office of Deputy
Clerk, the Deputy Clerk shall execute a bond with security to be approved by
the Corporate Authorities made payable to the village in the amount of
$20,000.  The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties of the office and the payment of all money received by the Deputy
Clerk according to the laws of the state and the ordinances of the village. 
The obligation of the sureties shall not extend to any loss sustained by the
insolvency, failure or closing of any bank organized and existing either
under the laws of the state or the United States wherein the Deputy Clerk has
placed funds in his custody, provided the bank has been approved by the
Corporate Authorities as a depositary for said funds.  The village shall pay
all premiums of each bond.  Each bond shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



(Ord. 217, passed 5-21-79)



§ 31.32  COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The Village Clerk shall receive compensation for each regular,
special and committee meeting attended in the sum of $125.



   (B)   The Village Clerk shall receive additional compensation of
$250 per month for maintaining office hours in the Municipal Building on
average of two hours per week on a monthly basis.



   (C)   In addition to the compensation herein provided, the Village
Clerk shall be entitled to receive reimbursement for reasonable expenses
incurred or advanced on behalf of the village.



(Ord. 997, passed 9-21-98; Am. Ord. 1145, passed 9-18-00; Am. Ord. 1887,
passed 3-6-17)



TREASURER



§ 31.40  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.



   The Village Treasurer shall be appointed by the Village President with
the advice and consent of the Board.  The Treasurer shall hold office
concurrently with the term of the Village President or until his successor is
duly appointed and qualified unless sooner removed.  The Treasurer shall be
compensated in such an amount as is from time to time established by the
Corporate Authorities.  The Village Treasurer shall be the custodian of all
village funds and shall keep a true and correct account of all monies
belonging to the village.  At the end of each month and at the end of each
fiscal year the Treasurer shall render an account under oath to the Corporate
Authorities showing the state of the village treasury on the date of the
account, the balance of money in the treasury, a statement of all money
received into the treasury, and on what account, together with a statement of
all disbursements made.  Provided, further, the Treasurer shall perform all
such duties as are from time to time set forth by the President and Board of
Trustees and the Illinois Municipal Code.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77; Am. Ord. 770, passed 8-30-93)



§ 31.41  BOND.



   Prior to entering upon the duties of Treasurer of the village, the
Treasurer shall execute a bond with security to be approved by the Corporate
Authorities made payable to the village in an amount of money that is not
less than three times the latest federal census population or any subsequent
census figure used for motor fuel tax purposes.  The bond shall be
conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the office of
Treasurer and the payment of all money received by the Treasurer according to
the laws of the state and the ordinances of the village.  The obligation of
the sureties shall not extend to any loss sustained by the insolvency,
failure or closing of any bank organized and existing either under the laws
of the state or the United States wherein the Treasurer has placed funds in
his custody, provided the bank has been approved by the Corporate Authorities
as a depositary for said funds.  The village shall pay all premiums of said
bond.  The bond shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



(Ord. 217, passed 5-21-79)



VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR



§ 31.50  OFFICE CREATED.



   The position of Village Administrator is hereby created subject to the
provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



§ 31.51  APPOINTMENT.



   The Village Administrator shall be appointed by the Village President
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees for an indefinite term
on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications without
consideration of race, age, color, handicap, national origin, sex, politics
or religious beliefs with special reference to education and actual
experience in, or knowledge of, accepted practice in respect to the
administration of local government and to the powers and duties of the office
as specified below.  At the time of his appointment, he need not be an
actual resident of the village provided that he becomes a resident of the
village within one year following the date of his appointment.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91; Am. Ord. 790, passed 2-2-94)



§ 31.52  [RESERVED].



§ 31.53  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Village Administrator shall be the chief administrative
officer of the village and shall be responsible to the President and the
Board of Trustees for the proper administration of the day-to-day business
affairs of the village.



   (B)   The Village Administrator shall have the following powers and
exercise these specific duties as follows:



      (1)   Personnel.  It shall be the duty of the Village
Administrator to direct, control, supervise and coordinate all village
departments and divisions thereof as may be created by the Board of Trustees
with the exception that the technical supervision of the Police Department
shall be provided by the Chief of Police.  He may recommend to the board of
Trustees the appointment of all officers, department heads and employees of
the village, except police personnel.  He may further recommend the
discipline, suspension of up to 15 days or removal of any nonpolice officer
or nonpolice employee when such discipline, suspension or removal shall be
consistent with the best interests of the village.  All recommendations for
appointment, discipline, suspension or removal shall be based on merit and
qualifications or disqualifications of such officer or employee without
regard to political belief or affiliation.  He shall recommend to the Board
of Trustees the salaries, wages, hours and conditions of employment of all
officers and employees under his jurisdiction.  Nothing herein shall limit
or take away from the Board of Trustees the final decision as to whom shall
be employed, suspended or removed or as to the amount of any salaries or
wages.



      (2)   Annual financial and administrative report.  The
Village Administrator shall prepare  or  be responsible for and submit to
the President and Board of Trustees within 60 days of conclusion of each
fiscal year a complete report of the financial and administrative activities
of the village for the preceding fiscal year.



      (3)   The annual budget, appropriation and levy ordinances. 
The Village Administrator shall prepare or cause to be prepared on or before
February 1 of each year an annual budget and shall submit the budget to the
President and Board of Trustees together with a message outlining its
important features.  He shall be responsible for its administration after
adoption provided that nothing herein shall limit the duties and
responsibilities of the Village Treasurer as provided for in state statutes
and the ordinances of the village.  The Village Administrator shall also
prepare and file each year the annual appropriation ordinance and the levy
ordinance.



      (4)   Signatory on Bank Accounts.  The Village Administrator
shall be designated as one of the signatories on all bank accounts of the
village.



      (5)   Purchases.  The Village Administrator shall purchase
all materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the
budget provided that no purchase shall be made, contract let or obligation
incurred for any item or service which exceeds the current budgeted amount
without a supplemental appropriation by the Board of Trustees.  The
authority of the Village Administrator to authorize purchase orders or
contracts or expend the funds of the village shall be limited to $10,000. 
The Village Administrator shall make recommendations to the President and
Board of Trustees as to whether a bid or contract officer is desirable or
undesirable or which of several contracts or bids submitted to the village is
the most desirable.



      (6)   The absence or vacancy of the Treasurer.  The Village
Administrator during any period of absence or vacancy of the Village
Treasurer shall immediately assume the duties and exercise the full powers of
the office as provided for in the village ordinances and state statutes.  In
no event shall the Village Administrator be required to obtain a bond in his
capacity as acting Treasurer if at the time of the exercise of such duties he
has a bond in effect in an amount not less than the amount provided for in §
31.55.



      (7)   Village property.  The Village Administrator  shall
keep a current inventory of all  real and personal property of the village
and the location of such property.  He shall be responsible for the care and
custody of all village property which is not by statute or ordinance assigned
to some other officer or body for care and control.



      (8)   Recommendations and advice.  The Village Administrator
shall recommend to the Board of Trustees the adoption of such measures as he
may deem necessary or expedient.  He shall advise the Board of Trustees of
the monthly financial condition of the village and the future financial needs
of the village and make such recommendations as he deems appropriate.



      (9)   Attendance at meetings.  The Village Administrator
shall be required to attend all the regular and special meetings of the Board
of Trustees unless expressly excused by the President or the Board of
Trustees.  He shall direct the preparation of the agenda for each such
meeting.  He shall present a report at each regular monthly meeting and be
prepared to answer any questions regarding the administration of the village.



      (10)   Pending legislation.  The Village Administrator shall
report to and consult with the President and Board of Trustees with respect
to pending and recommended legislation.



      (11)   Enforcement of ordinances.  The Village Administrator
shall assure that all village ordinances are effectively enforced, prepare
correspondence needs to direct or document village business decisions and
assist any citizens, outside agencies, developers, local community groups,
utility companies and the like and village staff in resolving governmental or
operation problems, bringing important matters to the attention of the Board
of Trustees.



      (12)   Economic development.  The Village Administrator shall
promote and assist the economic development and the controlled planned growth
of the village.



      (13)   Village spokesperson.  The Village Administrator shall
appear before citizen groups and other organizational meetings, make
speeches, attend ceremonial functions, and serve as a spokesperson for the
village in situations of mutual interest and concern with neighboring
municipalities as well as with federal and state agencies.



      (14)   Investigation of complaints.  The Village
Administrator shall investigate all nonpolice department complaints and
inquiries in relation to matters concerning the administration of the
government of the village and services maintained by the public utilities in
the village and shall see that all franchises, permits and privileges created
by the village are faithfully observed.



      (15)   General duties and powers.  The Village Administrator
shall perform such other duties and have such other powers as prescribed from
time to time by the President and Board of Trustees, including, but not
limited to, what is set forth on the Village Administrator job description
attached to Ordinance 1777 and incorporated by reference as if set forth in
full herein.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91; Am. Ord. 1297, passed 5-5-03; Am. Ord. 1684, passed 1-16-12; Am.
Ord. 1777, passed 5-15-14)



§ 31.54  COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES.



   The Village Administrator shall be paid such compensation as from time
to time is approved by motion or resolution of the Board of Trustees and
shall be reimbursed upon prior approval by the Board of Trustees for
out-of-pocket expenses incurred while in the performance of duties on behalf
of the village.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



§ 31.55  OATH AND BOND.



   The Village Administrator shall take an oath prescribed by law and
furnish a bond before entering upon the duties of his office in such sum as
may be required by the President and Board of Trustees.  The amount of the
bond shall not be less than the amount which may be required from time to
time by state statutes or the Board of Trustees.  The bond shall be
conditioned on the faithful performance of his duties and shall be
conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any neglect of
duty or any act of the Village Administrator.  The cost of the bond shall be
paid by the village.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



§ 31.56  CONFLICT OF INTEREST.



   The Village Administrator shall not be interested directly or
indirectly in any contract, work or business of the village, or in the sale
of any article to the village, or in the purchase of any property belonging
to the village or property sold for taxes or assessments or sold by virtue of
legal processes as a result of suit by the village.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



§ 31.57  OUTSIDE ACTIVITIES.



   The Village Administrator shall devote his entire time, attention and
energies to the business of the village and shall not be engaged in any other
business, teaching or consulting activity whether or not such activity is
pursued for gain, profit or other pecuniary advantage without the express
prior approval of the President and Board of Trustees.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



§ 31.58  EFFECT OF VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR ON POWERS OF PRESIDENT AND BOARD
OF TRUSTEES.



   The Village Administrator shall be subject to the authority and
direction of the President and Board of Trustees.  All functions, powers and
duties conferred or imposed on the Village Administrator shall be subject to
the superior right and power of the President and Board of Trustees to
supervise and administer the local government and affairs of the village. 
Except for internal administrative matters, the Village Administrator does
not set policy for the village; it is the duty and responsibility of the
Village Administrator to see that the policies and directives of the
President and Board of Trustees are implemented.  However, all acts and
things done by the Village Administrator pursuant to the provisions of this
subchapter shall, unless otherwise expressly provided herein, be final and
conclusive unless and until superseded by the action of the President and the
Board of Trustees.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



§ 31.59  ABSENCE OF VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR.



   During the absence or disability of the Village Administrator, the
Village President, with the advice and  consent of the Board of Trustees, 
may  designate some properly qualified village employee to act as temporary
Village Administrator.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



§ 31.60  PERFORMANCE EVALUATIONS.



   The Village Administrator shall be evaluated, in writing, at least once
a year.  The evaluation will be based upon the performance of his duties and
shall not reflect personality difference.  All criticisms that appear in the
written evaluation shall have been discussed with the Village Administrator
prior to the evaluation so that he will have had an opportunity to correct
any problems.  When a criticism is entered into the written evaluation, a
complete record will be entered, reflecting the exact nature of the problem
and what improvements have been made.  The written evaluation will be a
summary of the evaluations submitted by the President and the Trustees.  It
will be signed by the President and the Trustees.  The Village Administrator
will be presented the written evaluation in closed session and he will
examine its contents.  At that time he will have an opportunity to state his
opinion of the evaluation.  He shall be permitted to write on the evaluation
his opinion of the evaluation and discuss any section.  He will sign and
date the evaluation to denote that he has read it and has had an opportunity
to enter his written comments.  The original evaluation will be placed in a
history folder kept in the office of the President.  The folder will be
accessible to the Village Administrator and Trustees when accompanied by the
President.  The Village Administrator will receive a personal copy of the
evaluation.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



§ 31.61  REMOVAL AND RESIGNATION.



   The Village Administrator is an employee at will and may be removed at
any time upon the recommendation of the Village President with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91; Am. Ord. 1777, passed 5-5-14)



§ 31.62  PERSONNEL POLICY.



   The Village Administrator shall be salaried employee who shall be
subject to the provisions of the Personnel Policy of the village.  If there
is a conflict between this subchapter and the Personnel Policy, the
provisions of this subchapter shall control.



(Ord. 211, passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. 234, passed 12-3-79; Am. Ord. 656, passed
6-24-91)



VILLAGE ATTORNEY



§ 31.70  APPOINTMENT; DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.



   The Village Attorney shall be appointed by the Village President with
the advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees as provided by
statute at a fee fixed by resolution and shall hold office until his
successor is appointed and qualified.  He shall prosecute and defend all
suits at law or in equity when the village is a party or interested therein
or against or by any official on behalf of the village whenever authorized to
do so by the Corporate Authorities, provided that in all suits or proceedings
before courts or commissions, he may be paid a negotiated fee for same,
commensurate with and as agreed with the Corporate Authorities. He shall,
when requested, render advice on all legal questions arising concerning the
Village or its officers or employees and, upon request, shall reduce and
submit the same in writing.  He shall attend meetings of the Corporate
Authorities as required.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



VILLAGE AUDITOR



§ 31.80  APPOINTMENT; DUTIES.



   The Village Auditor shall be appointed by the Village President with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees and shall perform the duties
as required by law.  Upon completion of the annual audit of all village
monies, the Auditor shall provide the village  with sufficient copies of
same and file  certified copies with the appropriate state officials.  The
rate of compensation shall be determined by the Corporate Authorities prior
to each annual audit.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



VILLAGE ENGINEER



§ 31.90  APPOINTMENT; DUTIES.



   The Village Engineer shall be appointed by the Village President with
the advice and consent of the Trustees and shall hold office until his
successor is appointed and qualified.  He shall advise the Corporate
Authorities with respect to professional engineering matters when requested
by the Corporate Authorities.  He shall make current corrections to the
Village Map, Official Comprehensive Plan Map and the Village Zoning Map.  He
shall render professional engineering advice to the various committees,
boards and commissions of the village as required by law or as authorized by
the Corporate Authorities.  He shall be compensated in such manner as shall
be fixed by resolution.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



HUMAN RESOURCE MANAGER



§ 31.95  POSITION CREATED.



   There is hereby created with the Village of Channahon the position of
Human Resource Manager.



(Ord. 1761, passed 12-16-13)



§ 31.96  QUALIFICATION AND APPOINTMENT.



   (A)   The position of Human Resource Manager is an at-will position
which will be appointed by the Village President with advice and consent of
the Village Board and may be removed in the same manner.



   (B)   The Human Resource Manager will report directly to the Village
Administrator.



(Ord. 1761, passed 12-16-13)



§ 31.97  AUTHORITY.



   The Human Resource Manger is an administrative exempt salaried position.



(Ord. 1761, passed 12-16-13)

DIRECTORS OF DEPARTMENTS



§ 32.01  DUTIES.



   The Director of the various operating departments shall implement the
administrative details of specific departments in a manner that the Corporate
Authorities approve.  The Director of the various departments shall make
monthly reports to the Corporate Authorities and oftener if required, of the
matters and things pertaining to their respective departments showing
expenditures thereof.



(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77)



§ 32.02  APPOINTMENT.



   The Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees, shall appoint the Finance/Human Resource Department Trustee, the
Community and Legislative Affairs Trustee, the Public Works Department
Trustee, the Community Development Department Trustee, the Public
Safety/Emergency Support Trustee and the Technology/Community Image/ Code
Enforcement Trustee.



(Ord. 1298, passed 5-5-03; Am. Ord. 1392, passed 7-18-05; Am. Ord. 1743,
passed 5-6-13)



FINANCE/HUMAN RESOURCE DEPARTMENT



§ 32.10  ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.



   (A)   There is hereby established a position within the village
which shall be known as the Finance/Human Resource Department Trustee, who
shall be a member of the Board of Trustees.  The Finance/Human Resource
Department Trustee shall serve as a liaison between the Corporate
Authorities, the Village Administrator, the Finance Director and the Human
Resource Director with respect to matters and policies concerning:



      (1)   The finances and revenue of the village;



      (2)   The accounts and records of the village and all
officers, boards or departments required to keep or make accounts, records or
reports;



      (3)   The management and control of all monies collected and
paid out by the village and collection of money due the village;



      (4)   The Village Treasurer and auditing of the village
accounts and accounts of all special boards;



      (5)   The bonding of all of the officers and employees, who
have care and custody of any village funds;



      (6)   Insurance;



      (7)   Public health issues;



      (8)   The Village Employee Manual updates;



      (9)   Matters respecting collective bargaining;



      (10)   The updating and maintaining of new employee evaluation
forms;



      (11)   The impact of various employment related state and
federal regulations; and



      (12)   The coordination of employee benefits and insurance
policies.



   (B)   The Finance/Human Resource Department Trustee shall make such
reports to the Corporate Authorities as may be necessary to keep them
informed on all matters pertaining to the Finance Department, including any
failure to make payments or receive money due to the village and to all
records in relation to any such matters as he or she deems proper for action
by the Corporate Authorities.



(Ord. 1298, passed 5-5-03; Am. Ord. 1392, passed 7-18-05; Am. Ord. 1743,
passed 5-6-13)

§ 32.20  ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.



   (A)   There is hereby established a position within the village
which shall be known as the Community and Legislative Affairs Trustee who
shall be a member of the Board of Trustees.  The Community and Legislative
Affairs Trustee shall serve as a liaison between the Village Administrator
and the Corporate Authorities with respect to matters and policies relating
to:

      (2)   Handicapped;



      (3)   The sanitary condition of the village;



      (4)   Liaison between the village and the Community Events
Council;



      (5)   The Three Rivers Festival;



      (6)   Various community events;



      (7)   All issues pertaining to legislative affairs;



      (8)   Cable television;



      (9)   Solid waste disposal; and



      (10)   Recycling.



   (B)   The Community and Legislative Affairs Trustee shall make such
reports to the Corporate Authorities as may be necessary to keep them
informed on all matters pertaining to community affairs and shall make
records in relation to any such matters as he or she deems proper for action
by the Corporate Authorities.



(Ord. 1298, passed 5-5-03; Am. Ord. 1392, passed 7-18-05; Am. Ord. 1743,

and storm sewers and the construction of all street improvements, paving,

related issues.



   (B)   The Public Works Department Trustee shall make such reports to
the Corporate Authorities as may be necessary to keep them informed on all

(Ord. 161, passed 3-21-77;  Am. Ord. 295, passed 11-2-82; Am. Ord. 596,

Department Trustee shall serve as a liaison between the Corporate

   (B)   The Community Development Department  Trustee shall make such

(Ord. 1298, passed 5-5-03; Am. Ord. 1743, passed 5-6-13)



PUBLIC SAFETY/EMERGENCY SUPPORT



§ 32.50  ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.



   (A)   There is hereby established a position within the village
which shall be known as the Public Safety/Emergency Support Trustee, who
shall be a member of the Board of Trustees.  The Public Safety/Emergency

      (2)   The Board of Police and Fire Commissioners;



      (3)   The Police Pension Board;



      (4)   Coordination of emergency preparedness efforts between
the village administration, Public Works Department, Building Safety
Department, Police Department, emergency management agency and fire
protection district to prepare responses for a variety of emergencies; and



      (5)   Development and preparation of emergency preparedness
educational presentations to businesses, residents and village employees.



   (B)   The Public Safety/Emergency Support Trustee shall make such
reports to the Corporate Authorities as may be necessary to keep them
informed on all matters pertaining to the Department and shall make records
