GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 91.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ANIMAL.  Any animal, other than man, which may be affected by rabies,
including but not limited to horses, asses, mules, cattle, swine, sheep,
goats, geese, dogs and cats.



   ANIMAL CONTROL WARDEN.  Any person appointed by the President with the
advice and consent of the Board of Trustees to perform such duties as
required by this chapter.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



   CONFINED.  Restriction of an animal at all times by the owner, or his
agent, to an escape-proof building or other enclosure away from other animals
and the public. 



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



   DANGEROUS DOG.  Any individual dog which when either unmuzzled,
unleashed, or unattended by its owner, or a member of its owner's family, in
a vicious or terrorizing manner, approaches any person in an apparent
attitude of attack upon streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places.



   DOG.  All members of the family Canidae. 



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



   ENCLOSURE.  A fence or structure of a least six feet in height,
forming or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young
children, and suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other
measures which may be taken by the owner or keeper, such as tethering of a
vicious dog within the enclosure.  Such enclosure shall be securely enclosed
and locked and designed with secure sides, top and bottom and shall be
designed to prevent the animal from escaping from the enclosure.



   FOUND TO BE A VICIOUS DOG.  A dog is found to be vicious where:



      (1)   The Village Administrator, an Animal Control Officer, or
a law enforcement officer has conducted an investigation and made a finding
in writing that the dog is a vicious dog as defined above and, based on that
finding, the Village Administrator, an Animal Control Officer, or the Chief
of Police has declared in writing that the dog is a vicious dog, or



      (2)   The circuit court has found the dog to be a vicious dog
as defined above and has entered an order based on that finding.



   HAS BEEN BITTEN.  Has been seized with the teeth or jaws so that the
person or animal seized has been nipped, gripped, wounded or pierced and
further includes contact of saliva with any break or abrasion of the skin.



   IMPOUNDED.  Taken into the custody of the public pound in the city,
town or village where the vicious dog is found.



   INOCULATION AGAINST RABIES.  The injection of an antirabies vaccine
approved by the Department of Agriculture of the state.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



   LICENSED VETERINARIAN.  A veterinarian licensed by the State of
Illinois engaging in the practice of veterinary medicine.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



   OWNER.  A person having a right of property in a dog or other animal,
or who keeps or harbors a dog or other animal, or who has it in his care, or
acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits a dog or other domestic
animal to remain on or about any premise occupied by him.



   POUND.  Any facility approved by the Corporate Authorities for the
purpose of enforcing this chapter and used as a shelter for seized, stray,
homeless, abandoned, or unwanted dogs or other animals.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



   VICIOUS DOG  is defined to mean:



      (1)   Any individual dog that when unprovoked inflicts bites
or attacks a human being or other animal either on public or private property.



      (2)   Any individual dog with a known propensity, tendency or
disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise
endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals.



      (3)   Any individual dog that has a trait or characteristic
and a generally known reputation for viciousness, dangerousness or unprovoked
attacks upon human beings or other animals, unless handled in a particular
manner or with special equipment.



      (4)   Any individual dog which attacks a human being or
domestic animal without provocation.



      (5)   Any individual dog which has been found to be a
DANGEROUS DOG upon three separate occasions.



(Ord. 850, passed 6-5-95)



§ 91.02  APPOINTMENT OF ANIMAL CONTROL WARDEN; DUTIES.



   The President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees
shall appoint the Animal Control Warden and any Deputy Wardens.  The
compensation for the Animal Control Warden shall be fixed by the Corporate
Authorities.  It shall be the duty of the Animal Control Warden, through
education, stray control, impoundment, quarantine and any other means deemed
necessary to control and prevent stray animals in the village.  The Animal
Control Warden and any deputies are, for the purpose of enforcing this
chapter, clothed with power of a police officer in the village and within
such village is a peace officer in the enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter only, including issuance and service of citations and orders, and, as
such peace officer, has the power to make arrests on view or warrants for
violation of this chapter only and to execute and serve all warrants and
processes issued by any circuit court.  For the purpose of carrying out the
provisions of this chapter and making inspections hereunder, the Animal
Control Warden, or his duly authorized representative, or any officer of the
law may enter upon private premises to apprehend a stray dog or other animal,
a dangerous dog or other animal, a dog or other animal thought to be infected
with rabies, or to enforce any provision of this chapter, only with the
consent of the owner, lessee or agent of the premises, unless such consent
cannot be immediately secured and a clear and present danger will result to
the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the village if such animal
is not immediately apprehended.  If, after request therefor, the owner of
such dog or other animal shall refuse to deliver the dog or other animal to
the officer, the owner shall be in violation of this chapter.  However, such
Animal Control Warden is prohibited from carrying concealed weapons.  The
village police officers shall cooperate with the Animal Control Warden in
carrying out the provisions of this chapter.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.03  LIABILITY DISCLAIMED.



   Any person authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter shall
not be held responsible for any accident or property damages which may occur
while in the process of enforcing any provision of this chapter.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



LICENSING



§ 91.10  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   Every person who is an owner of any dog or cat in the village shall
register the dog or cat annually with the village on an application provided
by the Village Clerk for that purpose.  All licenses shall expire on January
31 in each year following the issuance of the license.  Such application
shall contain a statement of the name, breed, color and sex of each dog and
cat, the address at which such dog or cat  shall be kept and a certification
of the applicant that the dog or cat has been inoculated for rabies
prevention within the past 12 months, setting forth the name of the licensed
veterinarian who administered the inoculation and the date of the
inoculation.  All licenses shall be nontransferable.



(Ord. 849, passed 6-5-95)  Penalty, see § 91.99



§ 91.11  REGISTRATION FEES.



   (A)   There will not be any annual license fee for each dog and/or
cat registered prior to January 31st of each year.  If the animal is not
registered prior to January 31st, the annual fee shall be $7.  Licenses
issued for dogs/cats, which are acquired or moved into the village after
January 31st of each year will be no charge provided that the owner has
registered the animal within 30 days of occupancy.  If the animal is not
registered within the 30 days of occupancy, the animal fee will be $7.



   (B)   Provided, however, that all fees set forth in this paragraph
shall be reduced by 50% for dogs and cats whose owner is aged 65 or more and
for dogs which are specifically trained and function to assist handicapped
individuals, including but not limited to "seeing eye dogs."



(Ord. 849, passed 6-5-95; Am. Ord. 1159, passed 12-4-00)



§ 91.12  RECORD OF LICENSES.



   The Village Clerk shall keep a complete list of all licenses issued to
the owners of dogs and cats in the village.  The list shall include the name
and address of the owner, the name, breed, color and sex of the dog or cat
and the number of the license tag.



(Ord. 849, passed 6-5-95)



§ 91.13  ISSUANCE OF TAGS.



   The Village Clerk shall furnish to any person in compliance with §
91.10 a metal license tag with the year for which the registration is
effected.



(Ord. 849, passed 6-5-95; Am. Ord. 1159, passed 12-4-00)



§ 91.14  COLLAR OR HARNESS REQUIRED; REMOVAL OF TAGS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to own, keep or harbor any dog or cat
which is not within a completely enclosed structure or fenced yard in the
village unless the dog or cat has a collar or harness upon which a current
license tag is firmly affixed.  This provision shall not apply during the
first 30 days in the village after a dog or cat initially comes into
ownership or possession.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person other than an owner of a
dog or cat, Animal Control Warden or a licensed veterinarian to remove a
license tag from the collar or harness of a dog or cat.



(Ord. 849, passed 6-5-95)  Penalty, see § 91.99



CONTROL AND TREATMENT OF ANIMALS



§ 91.20  RUNNING AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT.



   Any animal or dog found running at large contrary to provisions of this
chapter shall be apprehended and impounded.  For this purpose, the Animal
Control Warden shall utilize any existing or available public or private
pound.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.21  NOTICE OF IMPOUNDMENT.



   (A)   When animals or dogs are apprehended and impounded by the
Animal Control Warden, he shall give notice within 48 hours of apprehension
and impoundment to the owner, if known.  Such notice shall either be mailed
to the last known address of the owner, posted at the address of the owner
listed on the license application, delivered personally or given
telephonically.  An affidavit or the testimony of the Animal Control Warden,
or his duly authorized agent, who mails, posts, delivers or gives such notice
shall be prima facie evidence of the receipt of such notice by the owner of
such animal or dog.  In case the owner of any impounded animal or dog
desires to make redemption thereof, he must satisfy the following conditions
in order for his animal or dog to be returned:



      (1)   He must present proof of current rabies inoculation and
registration, if applicable; or



      (2)   He must pay for the rabies inoculation of the animal or
dog, and registration, if applicable; and



      (3)   He must present current proof of a village license; and



      (4)   He must pay the pound for the board of the animal or dog
for the period it was impounded; and



      (5)   He must pay to the village $10 as an apprehension charge.



   (B)   These payments shall be in addition to any other penalties
which may be invoked under this chapter.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.22  UNREDEEMED ANIMALS.



   When not redeemed by the owner within five days following the giving of
the 48-hour notice required by § 91.21 herein, an animal or dog which has
been impounded for failure to be inoculated and licensed, if applicable, in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter, may be humanely dispatched,
offered for adoption or otherwise disposed of by the pound as a stray animal
or dog in accordance with law that exists or may hereafter exist.  This
chapter shall not prevent humane societies from engaging in activities set
forth by their charters provided, however, they are not inconsistent with
provisions of this chapter and other existing laws.  Any person purchasing
or adopting such animal or dog, with or without charge or donation, must pay
for the rabies inoculation of such animal or dog and license fee, if
applicable.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.23  ANIMALS EXHIBITING SIGNS OF RABIES.



   The owner of any dog or other animal which exhibits clinical signs of
rabies, whether or not such dog or other animal has been inoculated against
rabies, shall immediately notify the Animal Control Warden and shall promptly
confine such dog or other animal, or have it confined, under suitable
observation, for a period of at least ten days, unless officially authorized
by the Animal Control Warden, in writing, to release it sooner.  Any dog or
other animal in direct contact with such dog or other animal, whether or not
the exposed dog or other animal has been inoculated against rabies, may also
be confined as recommended by the Animal Control Warden.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.24  REPORT OF ANIMAL BITE.



   When the Animal Control Warden receives information that any person has
been bitten by a dog or other animal, the Animal Control Warden, or his duly
authorized representative, shall have such dog or other animal confined under
the observation of a licensed veterinarian for a period of ten days.  Such
veterinarian shall report the clinical condition of the dog or other animal
immediately, with confirmation in writing to the Animal Control Warden,
within 24 hours after the dog or other animal is presented for examination. 
The veterinarian shall give the owner's name, address, the date of
confinement, the breed, description, age and sex of such dog or other animal
on appropriate forms approved by the village.  The Animal Control Warden
shall notify the attending physician or responsible health agency.  At the
end of the confinement period, the veterinarian shall submit a written report
to the Animal Control Warden advising him of the final disposition of such
dog or other animal on appropriate forms approved by the village.  When
evidence is presented that such dog or other animal was inoculated against
rabies within the time prescribed by law, it may be confined in the house of
its owner, or in a manner which will prohibit it from biting any person, for
a period of ten days, if the Animal Control Warden, or other licensed
veterinarian, adjudges such confinement necessary.  The Animal Control
Warden may, by regulation, permit such confinement to be reduced to a period
of less than ten days.  At the end of the confinement period, such dog or
other animal shall be examined by the Animal Control Warden or another
licensed veterinarian.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.25  REFUSAL TO REPORT BITE.



   It is unlawful for any person having knowledge that any person has been
bitten by a dog or other animal to refuse to notify the Animal Control Warden
promptly.  It is unlawful for the owner of such dog or other animal to
euthanize, sell, give away, or otherwise dispose of any such dog or other
animal known to have bitten a person, until it is released by the Animal
Control Warden, or his authorized representative.  It is unlawful for the
owner of such dog or other animal to refuse or fail to comply with the
written or printed instructions made by the Animal Control Warden, or his
authorized representative.  If such instructions cannot be delivered in
person, they shall be mailed to the owner of such dog or other animal by
regular mail, postage prepaid.  The affidavit or testimony of the Animal
Control Warden, or his authorized representative, delivering or mailing such
instructions is prima facie evidence that the owner of such dog or such other
animal was notified of his responsibilities.  Any expense incurred in the
handling of any dog or other animal under this chapter shall be borne by the
owner.  For the purpose herein, IMMEDIATELY means by telephone, in person,
or by other than use of the mail.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.26  PREVENTION OF SPREAD OF RABIES.



   (A)   Whenever a case of rabies has occurred in the village, or when
the proper officials of the village are apprehensive of the spread of rabies,
the Animal Control Warden shall act to prevent its spread among dogs and
other animals.  The Animal Control Warden may order:



      (1)   That all dogs or other animals in the village be:



         (a)   Kept confined within an enclosure, or



         (b)   Kept muzzled and restrained by leash.



      (2)   That all owners or keepers of dogs or other animals take
prophylactic measures as they deem necessary to prevent the spread of rabies.



      (3)   Other measures as may be necessary to control the spread
of rabies.



   (B)   The Animal Control Warden may determine the area of the
village in which, and the period of time during which, such orders shall be
effective.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.27  GUIDE, SENTRY OR GUARD DOGS.



   Guide dogs for the blind or hearing impaired, support dogs for the
physically handicapped and sentry, guard or police-owned dogs are exempt from
this chapter; provided, no attack or injury to a person occurs while the dog
is performing duties as expected.  To qualify for exemption under this
chapter, each such dog shall be currently inoculated against rabies in
accordance with this chapter.  It shall be the duty of the owner of such
exempted dog to notify the Animal Control Warden of change of addresses.  In
the case of a sentry or guard dog, the owner shall keep the Animal Control
Warden advised of the location where such dog will be stationed.  The Animal
Control Warden shall provide the Police and Fire Departments with a
categorized list of such exempted dogs and shall promptly notify such
Departments of any address changes reported to him.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.28  LEASH REQUIREMENTS.



   The owner of any dog or other animal is deemed to have violated this
chapter whenever any such dog or other animal is outside the premises of its
owner and not under control by a leash or other similar instrumentality.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85; Am. Ord. 613, passed 10-24-90)  Penalty, see §
91.99



§ 91.29  RELINQUISHMENT.



   In the event an owner desires to relinquish or dispose of a dog or
other animal, the Animal Control Warden may do so upon receipt of a signed
authorization and release form and a donation of $10.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



§ 91.30  HUMANE TREATMENT.



   (A)   Each owner shall provide for each of his dogs and animals:



      (1)   Sufficient quantity of good quality, wholesome food and
water;



      (2)   Adequate shelter and protection from the weather and
unsanitary conditions;



      (3)   Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering; and



      (4)   Humane care and treatment.



   (B)   Any dog or animal that appears to be showing signs of neglect
in treatment shall be promptly examined by a licensed veterinarian and a
report made within 24 hours to the Animal Control Warden of the condition of
such dog or animal and any corrective measures to be taken.



   (C)   No person may own, capture, breed, trade or lease any dog or
animal or conduct in any manner or assist or patronize in any activity
involving a fight between two or more dogs or animals or the intentional
killing of any dog or animal for the purpose of wagering or entertainment.



   (D)   No person may knowingly poison or cause to be poisoned any dog
or any other animal.



   (E)   No person or owner may beat, cruelly treat, torment, overload,
overwork or otherwise abuse any dog or animal.  No owner may abandon any dog
or animal where it may become a public charge or where the dog or animal may
suffer injury, hunger or exposure.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)  Penalty, see § 91.99



§ 91.31  PUBLIC NUISANCE.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any owner to allow any dog or animal
to be a public nuisance defined as allowing said dogs or animals to:



      (1)   Defecate in any public or private place or on the lawn
of any person without immediately removing such matter;



      (2)   Disturb the peace by loud noises at any time of the day
or night;



      (3)   Enter any public or private place of business during
business hours;



      (4)   Threaten to attack without probable cause;



      (5)   Destroy any property without making restitution; or



      (6)   Interfere with, or be detrimental to, the general
welfare of the public or property rights of other persons.



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)  Penalty, see § 91.99



VICIOUS DOGS



§ 91.40  DEFINITION.



   (A)   A vicious dog is defined as follows:



      (1)   Any individual dog that when unprovoked inflicts bites
or attacks a human being or other animal either on public or private property.



      (2)   Any individual dog with a known propensity, tendency or
disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise
endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals.



      (3)   Any individual dog that has a trait or characteristic
and a generally known reputation for viciousness, dangerousness or unprovoked
attacks upon human beings or other animals, unless handled in a particular
manner or with special equipment.



      (4)   Any individual dog which attacks a human being or
domestic animal without provocation.



      (5)   Any individual dog which has been found to be a
DANGEROUS DOG upon three separate occasions.



   (B)   Vicious dogs shall not be classified in a manner that is
specific as to breed.



   (C)   If a dog is found to be a vicious dog, the dog shall be
subject to enclosure.



(Ord. 850, passed 6-5-95)



Cross-reference:



   For more definitions, see § 91.01



§ 91.41  EXCEPTION.



   No dog shall be deemed vicious if it bites, attacks or menaces a
trespasser on the property of its owner or harms or menaces anyone who has
tormented or abused it or is a professionally trained dog for law enforcement
or guard duties. 



(Ord. 850, passed 6-5-95)



§ 91.42  KEEPING OF VICIOUS DOGS PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any
dog which has been found to be a vicious dog unless such dog is at all times
kept in an enclosure.  The only times that a vicious dog may be allowed out
of the enclosure are:



      (1)   If it is necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain
veterinary care for the dog, or



      (2)   To comply with the order of a court of competent
jurisdiction, provided that the dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a
chain having a tensile strength of 300 pounds and not exceeding three feet in
length, and shall be under the direct control and supervision of the owner or
keeper of the dog.



   (B)   Any dog which has been found to be a vicious dog and which is
not confined to an enclosure shall be impounded and shall be turned over to a
licensed veterinarian for destruction by lethal injection.  The owner of
such vicious dog, if ascertainable, shall be notified by first class mail of
such impoundment.



   (C)   If the owner of the dog has not appealed the impoundment order
to the circuit court in the county in which the animal was impounded within
seven working days of the date of mailing such notice, the dog may be
humanely dispatched.  A dog found to be a vicious dog shall not be released
to the owner until the Animal Control Officer approves the enclosure as
defined in this chapter.



   (D)   In addition to any fines and/or penalties imposed  under this
chapter, the owner of any vicious dog subject to impoundment and destruction
may be responsible for all costs associated with the impoundment and
destruction of the dog as set out herein.



      (1)   If the owner does not appeal the impoundment order or
the impoundment is upheld by the circuit court following an appeal, the owner
shall be responsible for all costs as defined in division (D)(3).



      (2)   If the owner appeals the impoundment order and the
impoundment is vacated by the circuit court, the owner shall not be liable
for said costs.



      (3)   For the purposes of this section, COSTS shall include,
but are not limited to, reasonable boarding fees, food costs, necessary
veterinary care during the term of impoundment and destruction of the vicious
dog.



(Ord. 850, passed 6-5-95; Am. Ord. 1349, passed 6-8-04)  Penalty, see §
91.99



§ 91.43  SALE OR TRANSFER PROHIBITED.



   No owner or keeper of a vicious dog shall sell or give away the dog.



(Ord. 850, passed 6-5-95)  Penalty, see § 91.99



§ 91.44  PUBLIC NUISANCE.



   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to maintain a public nuisance by
permitting any dangerous dog or other animal to leave the premises of its
owner when not under control by leash or other recognized control methods.



   (B)   Guide dogs for the blind or hearing impaired, support dogs for
persons with disabilities, and sentry, guard, or police-owned dogs are exempt
from this chapter; provided, an attack or injury to person occurs while the
dog is performing duties as expected.  To qualify for exemption under this
chapter, each such dog shall be currently inoculated against rabies.  It
shall be the duty of the owner of such exempted dog to notify the village of
changes of address.  In the case of a sentry or guard dog, the owner of such
exempted dog shall keep the village advised of the location where such dog
will be stationed.  The village shall provide police and fire departments
with a categorized list of such exempted dogs, and shall promptly notify such
departments of any address changes reported to him.



(Ord. 850, passed 6-5-95)  Penalty, see § 91.99



§ 91.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   (1)   Any person violating any provisions of §§ 91.01
through 91.31 shall be punished by a fine as follows for each violation:



      First violation     $25



      Second violation    $30



      Third violation    $60



      Fourth violation    $250



      (2)   Each day such violation exists shall be considered a
separate and distinct offense. 



(Ord. 399, passed 9-9-85)



   (B)   Any person found to have violated § 91.40 through 91.44 shall
be fined not less than $25 nor more than $500 for every offense; any day upon
which an offense occurs shall be considered a separate violation.



(Ord. 850, passed 6-5-95)



CHAPTER 92:  EMERGENCY SERVICE AND DISASTER AGENCY



Section



   92.01   Establishment



   92.02   Coordinator



   92.03   Functions



   92.04   Service as a mobile support team



   92.05   Mutual aid agreements



   92.06   Emergency action



   92.07   Compensation



   92.08   Reimbursement by state



   92.09   Purchase and expenditures



   92.10   Oath



   92.11   Office space



   92.12   Fund created; commingling prohibited



   92.13   Local emergency plan



   92.14   Liability disclaimed



§ 92.01  ESTABLISHMENT.



   (A)   There is hereby created the Channahon Emergency Service and
Disaster Agency (ESDA) to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or
damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage or other
hostile action, or from natural or man-made disaster, in accordance with "The
Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Act of 1975."



   (B)   This ESDA shall consist of the coordinator and such additional
members as may be selected by the coordinator.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.02  COORDINATOR.



   (A)   The coordinator of the Channahon ESDA shall be appointed
annually by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees.



   (B)   The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the
organization, administration, training and operation of the ESDA, subject to
the direction and control of the Village President and the Board of Trustees
as provided by statute.



   (C)   In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability
to serve as the coordinator, the Village President or any person designated
by him shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as
provided in this chapter.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.03  FUNCTIONS.



   (A)   The Channahon ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions within
the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state ESDA plan and program
prepared by the Governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be
promulgated by the Governor, and in addition shall perform such duties
outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid
agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality or
quasi-municipality entered into as provided by "The State Emergency Services
and Disaster Agency Act of 1975".



   (B)   The Channahon ESDA shall also, when called upon by the Village
President, take whatever steps that can be taken to prevent, minimize, repair
and alleviate injury or damage resulting from any explosion, accident or
other event of a disastrous extent in the municipality in addition to
rendering such service in the event of disaster due to natural causes,
hostile action or explosion of bombs or missiles.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.04  SERVICE AS A MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM.



   (A)   All or any members of the Village ESDA organization may be
designated as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the
State ESDA as provided by law.



   (B)   The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by
the coordinator of the Channahon ESDA organization.



   (C)   Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee
or officer while serving on call to duty by the Governor, or the State
Director, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights
and immunities incident to such employment or office.  Any such member who
is not a paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, shall
receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by law.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.05  MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS.



   The coordinator of the Channahon ESDA may negotiate mutual aid
agreements with other villages or political subdivisions of the state, but no
such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the Village
President and the Board of Trustees and by the State Director of ESDA.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.06  EMERGENCY ACTION.



   If the Governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event
of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the
state of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile
action, or from man-made or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the
Channahon ESDA to cooperate fully with the State ESDA and with the Governor
in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.07  COMPENSATION.



   Members of the Channahon ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the
village, if called for training by the State Director of ESDA, shall receive
for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to
the position held; members who are not such village employees or officers
shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established
by the Village President and Board of Trustees.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.08  REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE.



   The State Treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund
any reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to
training members of the Channahon ESDA as prescribed by the State Director of
ESDA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support
team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the Governor
or State Director of ESDA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement
made by the state incident to ESDA activities as provided by law.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.09  PURCHASE AND EXPENDITURES.



   (A)   The Village President and the Board of Trustees may, on
recommendation of the village coordinator of the Channahon ESDA, authorize
any purchase of contracts necessary to place the village in a position to
combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear
or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety,
protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of
such disaster, or from man-made or natural disaster.



   (B)   In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the village
coordinator of the Channahon ESDA is authorized, on behalf of the village to
procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary
for such purposes, in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory
procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to village
contracts or obligations, as authorized by "The State Emergency Services and
Disaster Agency Act of 1975", provided that if the Village President and
Board of Trustees meet at such time he shall act subject to the directions
and restrictions imposed by that body.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.10  OATH.



   Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the Village ESDA
organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the
following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator:



   “I,                                   , do solemnly
swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and
allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of
the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and facilities
thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic;
that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose
of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon
which I am about to enter.  And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not
advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or
organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United
States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I
am affiliated with the Channahon ESDA organization, I will not advocate nor
become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or
violence."



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.11  OFFICE SPACE.



   The Village President and Board of Trustees are authorized to designate
space in a village building, or elsewhere, as may be provided, for the office
of the Channahon ESDA.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.12  FUND CREATED; COMMINGLING PROHIBITED.



   All sums of money appropriated or designated for use by the Channahon
ESDA shall be deposited in an account held separate and solely for ESDA and
the account shall be so designated.  No other money held by the village
shall be hereafter commingled with the ESDA funds.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.13  LOCAL EMERGENCY PLAN.



   The village shall prepare and keep current a local disaster emergency
plan for the area.  The Channahon ESDA director shall prepare and distribute
to all appropriate officials in written form a clear and complete statement
of the emergency responsibilities of all local departments and officials and
of the disaster chain of command.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



§ 92.14  LIABILITY DISCLAIMED.



   Neither the state, any municipal corporation of the state, including
the village, any political subdivision of the state, nor, except in cases of
negligence or willful misconduct, the Governor, the Director, other agencies,
or the agents, employees or representatives of any of them, engaged in any
emergency services and disaster operations or disaster activities, while
complying with or attempting to comply with this chapter or any rule or
regulation promulgated pursuant to this chapter is liable for the death of or
any injury to persons, or damage to property, as a result of such activity. 
This section does not, however, affect the right of any person to receive
benefits to which he would otherwise be entitled under this chapter under the
Worker's Compensation Act or the Worker's Occupation Diseases Act, or under
any pension law, and this section does not affect the right of any such
person to receive any benefits or compensation under any act of Congress.



(Ord. 229, passed 9-24-79)



CHAPTER 93:  HEALTH, SAFETY AND SANITATION



Section



General Safety and Sanitation Regulations



   93.01   Outdoor burning prohibited; exceptions



   93.02   Dumping of refuse prohibited



   93.03   Removal of unused gasoline storage tanks



Nuisances



   93.10   Conditions declared to be a nuisance



   93.11   Abatement



Weeds



   93.20   Definitions



   93.21   Weeds and grasses to be removed



   93.22   Notice of removal



   93.23   Removal by village



   93.24   Lien



   93.25   Foreclosure of lien



   93.26   Payment and release of lien



   93.27   Other remedies



 



   93.99   Penalty



Cross-Reference:



   Lawn grass, see §§ 151.02(D), 152.03(C)



GENERAL SAFETY AND SANITATION REGULATIONS



§ 93.01  OUTDOOR BURNING PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   No person may burn any material whatever outdoors, except as
stated in division (B).



   (B)   Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to prohibit
the burning of usual fuels in any furnace, fireplace or other heating unit or
plant situated within  any  building for the purpose of supplying  heat
for such building, nor shall anything herein contained be deemed to prohibit
the burning of leaves and limbs, outdoor cooking, food preparation and
controlled recreational bonfires.



(Ord. 243, passed 10-13-80)  Penalty, see § 93.99



§ 93.02  DUMPING OF REFUSE PROHIBITED.



   It shall be a violation of this section to dump any type of refuse
along any public highway, street, alleyway, village right-of-way or any
public property.



(Ord. 243, passed 10-13-80)  Penalty, see § 93.99



§ 93.03  REMOVAL OF UNUSED GASOLINE STORAGE TANKS.



   The rules and regulations adopted by the Office of the State Fire
Marshal regarding the removal of underground and aboveground storage tanks,
as stated in 41 Illinois Administrative Code Ch. 1, be and the same are
hereby adopted by reference and are incorporated herein as if fully set forth
in this section.



(Ord. 660, passed 7-1-91)



NUISANCES



§ 93.10  CONDITIONS DECLARED TO BE A NUISANCE.



   (A)   Prohibitions.  It is hereby declared to be a nuisance for any
person within the boundaries of the village or within any other area
designated herein to engage in the conduct set forth in this section or
permit any of the conditions hereinafter described to exist.



   (B)   Maintaining unwholesome business.  To establish, maintain and
carry on any offensive or unwholesome business within the limits of the
village and within one mile of the limits thereof.



   (C)   Packing houses and similar establishments.  To locate and
carry on any packing house, rendering establishment, tallow candlery, glue
and bone factory, soap factory and tannery within the limits of the village
and within one mile of the limits thereof.



   (D)   Air pollution.  To allow or permit any dense smoke, flue ash
or soot to come or be emitted from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or
other agency within the limits of the village and within one mile of the
limits thereof.



   (E)   Offensive odors.  To erect, continue or use any business,
building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or
manufacture which, by occasion of noxious exhalations, offensive smells or
otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or the
public.



   (F)   Noisy businesses.  To use any building or permit the use of
the building or rent the building to be used for any business or employment,
or for any purpose of pleasure or recreation, if such use shall, from its
noise or boisterous nature, disturb or destroy the peace of the neighborhood
in which such building or premises is situated or be dangerous or detrimental
to health.



   (G)   Watercourse obstruction.  To obstruct or pollute any
watercourse, ravine or gutter so as to cause water to stagnate therein, or to
permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any premises.



   (H)   Throwing offal in watercourse.  To throw or deposit or cause
to be thrown or deposited, any offal or other offensive matter, or the
carcass of any animal, in any watercourse, pond, spring or well, within the
limits of the village.  For purposes of this section the term "pond" shall
be considered to mean any exposed surface of water not less than 100 square
feet in area which has accumulated either by natural or artificial means, in
any depression or connected series of depressions of excavation, whether
existing naturally or created artificially.



   (I)   Slaughterhouse.  To slaughter or kill any cattle, hogs or
sheep or keep, maintain, or use in the village any house or place in which
the business of slaughtering any of said animals may be carried on.



   (J)   Offensive animal pens.  To own, use or keep any yard, pen,
place, railroad car or premises, in or upon  which cattle or other animals
shall  be  confined or kept, so as to be offensive to those residing in the
vicinity.



   (K)   Collection and deposit of offensive matter.  To cause or
suffer the carcass of any animal or vegetable matter, slops, refuse, swill,
suds, garbage, filth, stable drippings or offal, or noisome substance of any
kind, to be collected or deposited or to remain in any place in the
village.  Such refuse must be buried at least two feet below the surface of
the ground or burned in properly constructed incinerators or otherwise
properly eliminated.



   (L)   Maintaining unsightly yard.  To permit or maintain an
unsightly yard or premise where there is an accumulation or deposit of any
vehicle, equipment, material of any nature, waste or earth.



   (M)   Buildings dangerous to health.  To permit any building
structure or place to remain in such condition as to be dangerous to the
public health in any way.



   (N)   Keeping premises in filthy condition.  To keep or suffer to
be kept in a foul, offensive, nauseous or filthy condition, any chicken coop,
cow house, stable, cellar, vault, drain, privy, sewer or sink upon any
premises belonging to or occupied by the owner, or any railroad car,
building, yard, grounds and premises belonging to or occupied by him.



   (O)   Brewery.  To locate, erect or maintain any brewery or
distillery.



   (P)   Peddlers and hawkers.  To enter into or go upon any private
residence in the village for the purpose of peddling or selling without
having first been requested or invited to do so by the owner or owners or
occupant or occupants of the private residence.



   (Q)   Corrupting drinking water.  To corrupt or render unwholesome
or injure the water of any drinking hydrant, spring, stream, pond or lake.



   (R)   Combustible matter.  To cause or suffer grass, leaves,
underbrush or other combustible matter to be collected, deposited or to
remain on his premises in such quantities and condition so as to materially
increase the danger to property of others from fires.



   (S)   Obstructing highways.  To obstruct or encroach upon public
highways, private ways, streets, alleys and commons.



   (T)   Acts which endanger public health.  To commit  or  do  any
act  which  endangers  the  public health or results in annoyance or
discomfort to the public, whether such act is permitted or maintained on
private or public property.



   (U)   Common law and statutory nuisances.  To commit any offense
which is a nuisance according to the common law or made such by the statutes
of the state and not specifically enumerated by this section.



   (V)   Nuisance weeds.  The planting, or lack of maintaining, of any
weeds defined by this Code of Ordinances is strictly prohibited due to
pollution and a menace to health, as is any other weed or noxious weed as
defined by the Illinois Administrative Code.



(Ord. 214, passed 5-7-79; Am. Ord. 1650, passed 5-16-11)  Penalty, see §
93.99



§ 93.11  ABATEMENT.



   Whenever any nuisance exists or shall be found on any premises within
the village, whether such nuisance is one specifically recognized by
ordinance or not, the President is hereby authorized, in his discretion, to
cause the same to be summarily abated in such manner as he may direct and at
the expense of the party permitting or maintaining said nuisance.



(Ord. 214, passed 5-7-79)



WEEDS



§ 93.20  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   OWNER.  The legal owner, his agent, tenant, lessee, trustee, deed
purchaser under contract, land trust beneficiary or mortgagee in possession,
whether a natural person, the beneficiary of an equitable owner, corporation,
firm, company, association or partnership.



   PURPOSEFUL GARDEN or PLANTING BED. An area distinguished from common
lawn grasses by a maintained, delineating border.



   WEEDS.  To include, but not limited to, common burdock, giant ragweed,
common ragweed, thistles, common dandelion, perennial sow thistles, Canada
thistles and all its varieties, European bentwood, leafy spurge, Russian
knapwood, Johnson grass, yellow, foxtail, giant foxtail, ragweed, garlic
mustard, reed canarygrass, purple strife, common reed, buckthorn,
cockleburrs, jimson, poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lambsquarter,
wild lettuce, poison oak, poison sumac, bindweed, leafy spurge, knapweed,
hoary cress, any other wild, uncultivated or uncontrolled growth of
vegetation and any weeds determined to be noxious weeds by the Director of
the Department of Agriculture of the State of Illinois or defined by the
Illinois Administrative Code.



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83; Am. Ord. 900, passed 5-20-96; Am. Ord. 1650,
passed 5-16-11)



§ 93.21  WEEDS AND GRASSES TO BE REMOVED.



   (A)   It is hereby declared to be an offense for any owner of real
property within the village to permit any weeds, grass or plants to grow to a
height exceeding eight inches on improved property and 12 inches in height on
unimproved property. Soil stockpiles are determined to be unimproved property
for the purpose of this section. Any such plants or weeds exceeding such
height are hereby declared to be a nuisance. Landscaping including trees,
shrubs, ornamental vegetation (such as annual/perennial flowers and perennial
grasses) grown for aesthetic qualities in a purposeful garden or planting bed
can exceed the above requirements. In addition, vegetation height limitations
will not be applied to natural areas including all wetlands, native prairie
remnants, restoration areas, wetland mitigation areas, forest preserved
areas, preservation areas, and the like.



   (B)   No person owning, leasing, occupying or controlling any plot
of real estate within the village shall permit the growth of noxious weeds
thereon, as defined by this Code of Ordinances, the Illinois Administrative
Code and the Department of Agriculture of the State of Illinois. All weeds
shall be pulled or otherwise destroyed by the owner, lessee, tenant, occupant
or person in control of real estate in the village. Failure to destroy such
weeds within the designated period shall constitute a violation of this
chapter.



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83; Am. Ord. 900, passed 5-20-96; Am. Ord. 1650,
passed 5-16-11; Am. Ord. 1868, passed 9-6-16)  Penalty, see § 93.99



§ 93.22  NOTICE OF REMOVAL.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Director of  Development to serve
or cause to be served annually a notice upon the owner of any vacant premises
that if weeds or plants are permitted to grow in violation of the provisions
of § 93.21, the Director of Development may cause the weeds or plants to be
cut without further notice.



   (B)   It shall be the duty of the Director of Development to serve
or cause to be served a notice upon the owner or occupant of any improved
premises on which weeds or plants are permitted to grow in violation of the
provisions of § 93.21 and to demand the abatement of the nuisance within ten
days.  If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within ten days,
the Director of Development may cause the weeds or plants to be cut without
further notice.



   (C)   All notices provided for by this section shall be in writing
and delivered either by personal delivery  or by the mailing of the notice
in the United States mail with adequate prepaid postage thereunto affixed,
via registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to either the
last known address of the person or persons entitled thereto or to the
address of said owner or assessee as listed by the County Tax Assessor.  The
notice shall be deemed to be received either on the date of the actual
personal delivery to the person entitled thereto or on the date of its
mailing, if mailed in accordance herewith.



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83; Am. Ord. 900, passed 5-20-96)



§ 93.23  REMOVAL BY VILLAGE.



   If the owner or occupant of improved premises does not cut and remove
the weeds or plants within the ten-day period, the Director of Development
may proceed to have the weeds cut and removed at the expense of the village
with the cutting and removal charges and expenses charged to and paid by the
owner.  The Director of Development may have weeds cut and removed on
unimproved premises at any time when a violation exists at the expense of the
village with the cutting and removal charges and expenses charged to and paid
by the owner.



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83; Am. Ord. 900, passed 5-20-96)



§ 93.24  LIEN.



   Charges for weed cutting shall be a lien upon the real property. 
Whenever a bill for weed cutting remains unpaid, the Village Clerk, or the
person performing the service by authority of the village, shall file with
the County Recorder of Deeds within 60 days after the expense is incurred a
notice of lien in the name of the village or in the name of the person
performing the service.  The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn
statement setting forth the legal description of the real property and a
common address sufficient for identification thereof; the amount of the cost
and expense incurred or payable for the removal of the weeds; and the date or
dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the village.  The failure
of the Village Clerk to mail the lien notice or record the notice or the
failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to
foreclose the lien, as provided for in the following section.  Expenses
shall include but not be limited to the expenses of the cutting and removal,
service and filing expenses and reasonable attorney's fees.



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83)



§ 93.25  FORECLOSURE OF LIEN.



   Property subject to a lien for unpaid weed cutting charges shall be
sold for nonpayment of said charges and the proceeds of such sale shall be
applied to pay the charges after deducting costs, as is the case in the
foreclosure of statutory liens.  Such foreclosure shall be by a bill in
equity in the name of the village within two  years of the date of the
cutting and removal of the weeds.  The Village Attorney shall hereby be
authorized and directed, following approval of the Corporate Authorities, to
institute such proceedings in the name of the village against any owner for
which a bill for weed cutting has remained unpaid for a period of 60 days
after the expense has been incurred in any court having jurisdiction over
such matters.  The owner shall also be required to pay any and all costs and
expenses of the village for the foreclosure of the lien including, but not
limited to, reasonable attorney's fees.  In addition to foreclosure of the
lien, the village may institute any necessary proceedings in any court of law
to recover from the owner the costs and expenses of the village in cutting
and removing the weeds, including but not limited to reasonable attorney's
fees.



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83)



§ 93.26  PAYMENT AND RELEASE OF LIEN.



   Upon payment of all of the expenses of the village, the lien shall be
released by the village in the same manner as the filing of the lien.



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83)



§ 93.27  OTHER REMEDIES.



   The provisions of this subchapter are not exclusive and the village
expressly reserves all other remedies, whether by ordinance, statute or
common law, which may be used to effect the intent of this subchapter.



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83)



§ 93.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   All persons acting in violation of the provisions of §§
93.01 or 93.02 shall be fined not less than $25 for each violation.  A
separate violation shall be deemed committed on each day during and on which
a violation occurs or continues. 



(Ord. 243, passed 10-13-80)



   (B)   Any person violating any of the provisions of § 93.10 shall
be fined not less than $25 nor more than $500 for each offense and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during and on which a violation
occurs or continues. 



(Ord. 214, passed 5-7-79)



   (C)   Any owner violating any provision of §§ 93.20 through 93.27
shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $500 for each offense and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
such offense continues unabated after ten days from the service of the
notice. 



(Ord. 330, passed 11-7-83)



CHAPTER 94:  RECYCLING PROGRAM



Section



   94.01   Definitions



   94.02   Recycling program established



   94.03   Disposal of municipal waste prohibited



   94.04   Recycling containers



   94.05   Separation of recyclables and placement for recyclables
removal



   94.06   Mandatory recycling



   94.07   Collection by unauthorized persons



 



   94.99   Penalty



§ 94.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   MUNICIPAL WASTE.  Garbage, general household and commercial waste,
landscape waste and construction or demolition debris. 



(Ord. 661, passed 7-1-91)



   RECYCLABLES.  Material having an economic value in the secondary
materials market, acceptable for collection by the village's recycling
contractor, which currently include glass containers (three color), aluminum
and bimetal beverages cans, steel and tin food cans, HDPE #2 plastic milk and
water jugs, HDPE #2 colored laundry bottles, PET #1 beverage bottles, and all
newspapers.  Additional items shall be added to the program in the future
which are mutually agreed upon between the village and Banner Western
Disposal Service. 



(Ord. 715, passed 6-15-92)



§ 94.02  RECYCLING PROGRAM ESTABLISHED.



   There is hereby established a recycling program for the mandatory
separating of recyclables from garbage and rubbish for residents in the
village.



(Ord. 715, passed 6-15-92)



§ 94.03  DISPOSAL OF MUNICIPAL WASTE PROHIBITED.



   It shall be a violation of this section to abandon, dump or deposit any
type of municipal waste at the Channahon Township recycling center.



(Ord. 661, passed 7-1-91)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.04  RECYCLING CONTAINERS.



   All residents shall use village approved and issued recycling
containers in conjunction with the village's recycling program.  After
initial distribution of containers to village residents, replacement
containers will be available for rental by residents from the village upon
such terms and conditions as are from time to time established by the Village
Administrator.



(Ord. 715, passed 6-15-92)



§ 94.05  SEPARATION OF RECYCLABLES AND PLACEMENT FOR RECYCLABLES REMOVAL.



   All products the village designates as recyclable shall be prepared and
separated from all other refuse by residents and placed in village approved
and issued containers, as required and shall be collected by the village
curbside recycling contractor.  Recyclables shall be placed in recycling
containers at curbside to be collected at times designated by the village.



(Ord. 715, passed 6-15-92)



§ 94.06  MANDATORY RECYCLING.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, for collection, removal
or disposal, any residential, household or solid waste, refuse or garbage
which also contains recyclable materials.



(Ord. 715, passed 6-15-92)



§ 94.07  COLLECTION BY AUTHORIZED PERSONS.



   From time of placement of acceptable recyclables at the curb from
collection in accordance with the terms hereof, the acceptable recyclables,
as defined in § 94.01, shall be and become the property of the village's
curbside recycling contractor.  It shall be a violation of this chapter for
any person authorized by the village to collect or pick up or cause to be
collected or picked up any such items.  Any and each such collection in
violation hereof from one or more locations shall constitute a separate and
distinct offense punishable as set forth in § 94.99.



(Ord. 715, passed 6-15-92)



§ 94.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   All persons found to have violated any provision of § 94.03
shall be fined not less than $50 nor more than $500 for each violation.  A
separate violation shall be deemed committed on each day during and on which
a violation occurs or continues. 



(Ord. 661, passed 7-1-91)



   (B)   Any person(s) who violates §§ 94.04 through 94.07 is subject
to the penalties set out as follows:



      (1)   Any person convicted of a violation of this chapter is
guilty of a petty offense and shall be fined not less than $50 nor more than
$500.



      (2)   The penalties prescribed in this section are in addition
to, and not in lieu of, any other rights, remedies and penalties which the
village may otherwise seek to impose and may be available at law or in
equity. 



(Ord. 715, passed 6-15-92)

DRAINAGE CULVERTS



§ 95.01  OBSTRUCTION OF DRAINAGE DITCHES.



   No person shall in any manner obstruct or alter the flow of surface
drainage water upon the streets or within the drainage ditches or storm
sewers upon the public rights-of-way within the confines of the corporate
limits of the village; and all persons, before constructing or making any
crossing of any such surface drainage ditch with a private driveway, sidewalk
or other similar crossing which might or could obstruct the flow of water
within any such drainage ditch, shall install at such crossing a surface
drainage culvert or culverts of sufficient size to carry the water within the
drainage ditch with the approval of the Village Engineer or Director of
Public Works. The construction of all driveways shall be in accordance with
§ 154.52, Driveways.



(Ord. 76, passed 5-18-69; Am. Ord. 1531, passed 4-7-08)  Penalty, see §
95.99



§ 95.02  DRAINAGE CULVERT PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No person shall commence with the installation, enlargement,
alteration, construction, repair, or removal of any surface drainage culvert
or similar structure, or any part or parts thereof, in or upon the streets or
public rights-of-way in the village unless and until a permit for such
installation, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal shall
first be obtained by the person or persons desiring to do the same, or their
agents, from the Village Clerk; and it shall be unlawful to proceed with such
installation, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal unless
such permit shall first have been obtained and if after such permit shall
have been granted, the operations called for by said permit shall not be
commenced within 90 days after the date thereof, or if such operations are
not completed within a reasonable time, then such permit shall be void and no
operations thereunder shall be commenced or completed until a new permit
shall be issued and fees as herein fixed for the original permit shall be
paid for such new permit.



(Ord. 76, passed 5-18-69)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.03  PERMIT FEE.



   The fee for the issuance of each such permit as herein provided for
shall be the sum of $5.



(Ord. 76, passed 5-18-69)



§ 95.04  APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.



   Application for such permits shall be made by the persons desiring the
same, or their agents, to the Village Clerk.  When application is made,
plans and specifications shall be submitted for examination and approval by
the Director of Roads and Drainage, or his authorized representative.  Plans
and specifications shall comply with all applicable village ordinances and
regulations.  Upon approval, the Village Clerk shall issue or cause to be
issued a permit and shall maintain a copy thereof, together with the
application on file.



(Ord. 76, passed 5-18-69)



§ 95.05  INSPECTION OF CULVERTS.



   The Director of Roads and Drainage, or his representative, shall make
an inspection of the site of the culvert to be installed, enlarged,
constructed, altered, repaired or removed prior to the issuance of the permit
herein provided for, and shall make such additional inspections as may be
necessary and reasonable during the operations for which the permit is issued
and shall make a final inspection of the same after the installation,
enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal provided for in the
permit shall be completed.  In the event that such installation,
enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal of any culvert is
not done in reasonable compliance with the application in a good and
workmanlike manner so that the same shall operate properly, the person to
whom such permit is issued shall make such alterations as may be required to
cause conformance with the application so that the same exists in good
operating condition.



(Ord. 76, passed 5-18-69)



EXCAVATION



§ 95.10  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   No person shall make or cause any cutting, excavation  or 
damage  to  any public  street, alley, or highway within the village under
the jurisdiction and control of the village without first obtaining apermit
to do so from the Village Director of Public Works.  Streets shall be
defined to include any hard-surfaced slab, shoulders and drainage ditches.



   (B)   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to construction
of facilities in public rights-of-way, which is governed by Chapter 54 of
this code.



(Ord. 331, passed 11-7-83; Am. Ord. 1508, passed 11-19-07)  Penalty, see §
95.99



§ 95.11  APPLICATION; FEE.



   Each person desiring to cut or excavate within the right-of-way of any
such public street, alley or highway shall file an application for a permit
to do so with the Village Clerk.  The application shall be accompanied with
engineering plans and specifications for such cutting or excavation
sufficiently detailed to enable the Village Engineer to evaluate such request
and the possible effect or damage to such right-of-way and the public
improvements therein.  The application shall be accompanied with a
nonrefundable fee in the sum of $100.



(Ord. 331, passed 11-7-83)



§ 95.12  REVIEW BY VILLAGE ENGINEER.



   Upon the receipt of each application for such cutting or excavation,
the Village Clerk shall send a copy of the application and the plans and
specifications submitted therewith to the Village Engineer for his review and
recommendation.  He shall inform the village of the maximum possible damage
which may result to the street, alley or highway and the improvements
necessary to repair said street, alley or highway.



(Ord. 331, passed 11-7-83)



§ 95.13  APPROVAL OR REJECTION OF APPLICATION; ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.



   (A)   The application and the report of the Village Engineer shall
be submitted to the Director of the Department of Roads and Drainage for
approval or rejection.  The applicant shall also furnish the village with a
bond or letter of credit in a form approved by the Village Attorney with good
and sufficient corporate surety so as to reimburse the village for the cost
of any and all repairs and related expenses such as reasonable engineering
and attorney's fees incurred by the village for the maintenance and repair of
the street, alley or highway as a result of said cutting or excavation within
a period of two years of the completion  of such cutting  or excavation 
and  written approval of the Village Engineer.  Any bond or letter of
credit shall be in a sum equal to one and one-half times the amount of the
estimate of the Village Engineer of the maximum possible damage as
aforesaid.  The applicant shall also indemnify and hold harmless the
village, its officers, elected and appointed officials and agents of and from
any and all claims, causes of action, judgments, damages and the like which
arise out of or from the cutting or excavation of any street, alley or
highway in the village.



   (B)   A permit shall be issued by the Village Clerk upon the
direction of the Director of the Department of Roads and Drainage when such
cutting or excavation is reasonably necessary and all other provisions of
this subchapter have been satisfied.  The permit will terminate and will not
be valid if the cutting or excavation has not commenced prior to the
expiration of six months from the date of issuance.



(Ord. 331, passed 11-7-83)



§ 95.14  EXCAVATION REQUIREMENTS.



   All cutting and excavation across or along a street, alley or highway
shall be made in a manner so as to allow at least one single lane of vehicle
traffic at all times along the site of the cutting or excavation.  All
cuttings or excavations shall at all times be properly fenced, barricaded or
guarded and at night shall be lighted to prevent injury to any persons and
damage to any vehicles or other personal property.



(Ord. 331, passed 11-7-83)



§ 95.15  RESTORATION; INSPECTION.



   The applicant shall notify the Village Engineer upon the completion of
any such cutting or excavation.  Within 30 days from the date of such
cutting or excavation, the applicant shall expeditiously restore the street,
alley or highway disturbed by such cutting or excavation to substantially the
condition that existed prior to such cutting or excavation.  The Village
Engineer shall then personally inspect the restoration and in writing inform
the village of the acceptance of the restoration.



(Ord. 331, passed 11-7-83)



§ 95.20  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   HOUSE.  All buildings used for dwellings and business purposes.



§ 95.21  NUMBER OF HOUSES.



   (A)   All houses in the village shall be numbered, and it is made
the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of every house in the
village to number or cause the same to be numbered in the manner as is
provided in this subchapter.



   (B)   One number on each side of each thorough-fare shall be
allotted to each 20 feet of frontage.  The numbering shall begin at State
Street and Madison Street in the city of Chicago extending outwardly.  The
number system shall increase southerly beginning with the present corporate
limits on the north of Troy Township with number 18300.  The number system
shall increase westerly beginning with the present corporate limits on the
east of Troy and Channahon Township with number 21600.



   (C)   Each block break will be every 660 feet.  If a street
intersects within three property numbers of a hundred number break, the break
will be shifted to the centerline of intersecting streets.



   (D)   Each block will be divided into 66 numbers - 33 odd and 33
even.



   (E)   On north-south streets, even numbers will be on the west side
and odd numbers on the east sides.



   (F)   On east-west streets, even numbers will be on the north sides
while odd numbers will be on the south sides.



   (G)   Crescents will be numbered consecutively from their
intersection of beginning to their intersection of ending.  Corner lots can
have two addresses. Which one is applicable depends on which street the front
of the house faces.



   (H)   Streets will be considered as trending in the direction in
which they cover the greatest distance.  Streets that cover roughly equal
distances both north-south and east-west will be considered as north-south
trending when they follow a southwest-northwest bearing and east-west
trending when they follow a southeast-northwest bearing.



   (I)   Only one property number per street frontage will be assigned
for single-family and industrial parcels.  A lot that is on a corner may use
only one address that corresponds to the front entrance of the use. 
Multiple-family and commercial lots will be assigned one property number per
major entrance per street frontage.



   (J)   Each of the figures of numbers so to be placed on houses shall
not be less than four inches in height and shall be so marked as to be
distinctly and easily read and shall be of design to be approved by the
village.  Such numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous place on or near the
front of the house so that the same are plainly visible and readable by a
person with normal vision from the street or highway on which the parcel or
lot adjoins.  It shall be the obligation of the owner or occupant of the
house to place the house numbers within six months of the date of this
subchapter.



   (K)   Whenever any house or building shall have been numbered or
renumbered in accordance with this subchapter, such number shall not be
changed or altered unless upon application to the Village Clerk and upon new
number being assigned therefore in accordance with this subchapter.



   (L)   In all cases where numbers have been assigned on any street,
in pursuance hereof or of any subchapter hereafter passed, it shall be the
duty of the Village Clerk to adjust and reassign numbers as may be required
from time to time, and in all cases where there is a mistake or conflict in
numbers, the Clerk shall direct and make proper adjustment of the same.



(Ord. 612, passed 10-24-90)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.22  ANNEXED TERRITORY TO CONFORM.



   All territory hereinafter to be annexed to the village shall conform to
the system of numbering provided in this subchapter.  Maps shall be prepared
of all streets required to be numbered, drawn to an accurate  scale showing
all intersection streets and the location of the front of all houses and each
front entrance of the same.  The whole length of streets shall be divided
into spaces or lots of 20 feet frontage as herein provided.  A number shall
be given for each space, and the number coinciding most nearly with the
location of any front entrance shall be the number of the same.  Consecutive
numbers shall be placed directly opposite on lines at right angles to the
street.  All numbers placed on houses under this subchapter shall be
indicated on such maps.  The maps shall be kept on file in the office of the
Village Clerk.



(Ord. 612, passed 10-24-90)



§ 95.23  REMOVING OR DEFACING NUMBERS.



   No person shall remove or deface any house number placed upon any house
in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter.  No person shall
retain any number of his house other than that provided by the provisions of
this subchapter.  No owner, agent or person in possession of any house shall
refuse or neglect to number such house or cause the same to be numbered in
conformity with this subchapter.



(Ord. 612, passed 10-24-90)  Penalty, see § 95.99



DEPOSITION OF SNOW AND SLUSH



§ 95.35  DEPOSITION OF SNOW AND SLUSH UPON PUBLIC STREETS PROHIBITED.



   No snow or slush removed from private property by way of shoveling,
plowing or blowing shall be deposited upon the paved section of any public
road, street or highway within the village.



(Ord. 576, passed 4-2-90)  Penalty, see § 95.99



MAILBOXES AND OTHER STRUCTURES



§ 95.45  INSTALLATION.



   (A)   Mailboxes and their installation shall conform to the
specifications of the United States Postmaster General.  The mailbox shall
be mounted such that the door is six inches behind the back of the curb or 24
inches from the edge of pavement on rural roads, 42 inches high and located
on the side of the street as specified by the local post office. No part of
the box or structure shall be closer than six inches or 24 inches as
indicated above.



   (B)   Mailboxes shall not be installed within the radius of a
cul-de-sac. Mailboxes serving lots fronting on the radius of a cul-de-sac
shall be placed at the entrance to the cul-de-sac, the location to be
approved by the Post Master and Village Building and Zoning Officer.



(Ord. 813, passed 8-1-94; Am. Ord. 951, passed 9-15-97; Am. Ord. 1504, passed
9-17-07)



§ 95.46  MOUNTING POSTS.



   The objective of this section is to provide guidance to the homeowner
as to what types of posts are desirable.  Posts smaller or less substantial
(decorative posts) are subject to damage as discussed in § 95.48.  Posts
more extensive than mentioned, such as masonry, steel beams, or poured
concrete, are dangerous to snow removal equipment and other vehicles due to
their excessive resistance to knockdown and are, therefore, prohibited within
the public right-of-way.  The following specifications are advisory;
however, residents are encouraged to adhere to these guidelines in mounting
roadside mailboxes.  Mailboxes damaged by snow discharge, per § 95.48, that
are not installed in conformance with these specifications will not be
repaired by the village.

Mounting

Concrete
 
Angle iron & bolts (4-1/8" bolts min)
