APPENDIX E:  SANITARY SEWER MATERIAL STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS



   (A)   General.



      (1)   All developments shall be provided with sanitary sewers
and appurtenances designed in accordance with this appendix.



      (2)   All sanitary sewer improvements shall be installed in
accordance with the material installation and testing requirements of the
latest edition of the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main
Construction in Illinois, unless otherwise modified in this section.



      (3)   Specification references made herein for manufactured
items, such as pipe, fittings and manholes, refer to designations of the
American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM), the American Water Works
Association (AWWA) or the American National Standards Institute (ANSI).



   (B)   Basic design standards.



      (1)   The design of the sanitary sewer system shall be in
accordance with the requirements of the village and of the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency's latest edition of Title 35 of the Illinois
Administrative Code, Subtitle C, Chapter 11, Part 370.



      (2)   All sewers shall be designed to accommodate an ultimate
service area as defined by the Village Engineer.



      (3)   Sewers shall be placed only in public rights of way or
in easements.  The location of proposed extensions to the existing sanitary
sewer system shall be approved by the Village Engineer.



      (4)   Sewer design hydraulics.



         (a)   Sanitary gravity sewers shall be designed to
provide design flow capacity, without surcharging, using the formula
specified in the latest edition of the Illinois Administrative Code.



         (b)   Design mean velocity, flowing full, shall not be
less than two feet per second.  If velocity exceeds 15 feet per second,
erosion and shock protection measures shall be provided.



      (5)   Minimum sewer size.



         (a)   Minimum sanitary sewer size shall be eight-inch
diameter.



         (b)   Minimum building sanitary service sewer size shall
be six-inch diameter.



      (6)   Alignment.  Sewers shall be laid straight, in both
horizontal and vertical planes, between manholes.



      (7)   Sewer size changes. 



         (a)   Sanitary sewer of different diameters shall join
only at manholes.



         (b)    The invert elevations shall be adjusted to
maintain a uniform energy gradient by matching the 0.8 depth points of
different diameters.



      (8)   Sanitary sewer manholes.



         (a)   Manholes shall be provided at the following
locations:



            1.   Termination of existing and future lines;



            2.   Changes in direction, horizontal or vertical;



            3.   Changes in shaped or pipe size; and



            4.   Junctions with other sanitary sewers.



         (b)   Access spacing shall be:



 


SEWER PIPE SIZE (in inches)

 

MAXIMUM INTERVAL (in feet)




8 - 15

 

400




18 - 54

 

500




60 or larger

 

1,000




 



         (c)   A drop manhole shall be provided for manholes with
any pipe having a difference in invert elevation more than 24 inches above
the invert of the sewers leaving such manholes.



         (d)   Where flows, pipe size or other conditions
dictate, special manholes or junction chambers shall be designed and
constructed.



         (e)   Minimum manhole diameter.



 


SEWER PIPE SIZE (in inches)

 

MANHOLE DIAMETER (in inches)




8 - 18

 

48




21 - 36

 

60




For sewers greater than 36-inch diameter, manhole shall have offset riser of
48-inch inside diameter.




 



         (f)   Adjustment.  No more than two precast concrete
adjusting rings, with six inches maximum height adjustment, shall be allowed.



      (9)   Sewer depth.  Sanitary sewers shall be constructed at a
minimum depth of four feet and shall be deep enough to provide an outfall for
all sanitary sewage within the ultimate service area, both existing and
future.



   (C)   Material specifications.  All sanitary sewer system elements
shall conform to the following specifications:



   (1)   Sewer and service connection pipe.



         (a)   Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe:  ASTM D-3034, SDR
26 minimum strength.



         (b)   Reinforced concrete pipe:  circular
reinforcement, minimum Class 3, Wall B, ASTM C-76.



         (c)   ABS composite pipe:  ASTM D-2680 for eight-inch
and larger, and ASTM D-2751 for six-inch.



         (d)   Ductile iron pipe:  ANSI A21.51 (AWWA C-151),
minimum thickness Class 52 per ANSI A21.51 (AWWA C-150), cement-lined.



      (2)   Sewer and service connection pipe joints.



         (a)   PVC pipe:  flexible elastomeric seal joints, ASTM
D-3212.



         (b)   Reinforced concrete pipe:  continuous O-ring
gaskets, ASTM C-361.



         (c)   ABS composite pipe:  solvent-welded joints, ASTM
D-2680.



         (d)   Ductile iron pipe:  rubber gasket joints, ANSI
A21.11 (AWWA C-111).



      (3)   Sewer and service connection pipe fittings.



         (a)   PVC:  molded PVC fittings, ASTM D-3034, SDR 26
minimum strength.



         (b)   ABS composite:  ASTM D-2680, for eight-inch and
larger, and ASTM D-2751 for six-inch.



         (c)   Ductile iron:  ANSI A21.10 (AWWA C-110).



      (4)   Casing pipes.  Steel pipe:  ASTM A-120, 3/8" minimum
thickness.     



      (5)   Manholes.         



         (a)   Concrete.  Precast reinforced concrete ASTM C-478
with tongue-and-groove joints sealed with gaskets conforming to ASTM C-443 or
bituminous jointing material.



         (b)   Pipe seals.  All pipe connection openings shall
be precast with resilient rubber water-tight pipe-to-manhole sleeves or
seals, per ASTM C-923.  Rubber gasketed manhole coupling shall be
Kor-N-Seal, A-Lok, or equal.



         (c)   Chimney seals.  External, flexible, water-tight
rubber sleeves, conforming to the applicable requirements of ASTM C-923, with
stainless steel bands; shall extend from the manhole cone to the manhole
frame and shall be provided on all sanitary manholes.  Where conditions
prohibit the use of an external seal, an internal seal shall be used.



         (d)   Top section.  Top cone shall be offset type
designed to accept an external chimney seal.  Flat slabs shall be provided
where sufficient height is not available for a cone.



         (e)   Bottom sections.  All bottom sections shall be
monolithically precast, including bases and invert flowlines.



         (f)   Steps.  Cast in place, E.J.I.W. No. 8518 or
steel-reinforced plastic, conforming to OSHA standards, 16-inch on center.



      (6)   Castings.  Manhole frame and cover:  E.J.l.W. No.
1020, with machined bearing surfaces and self-sealing Type A heavy duty lid,
embossed "SANITARY" and "VILLAGE OF CHANNAHON".



      (7)   Pipe bedding and cover material and trench backfill. 
IDOT gradation CA-7 crushed stone or crushed gravel meeting the following
gradation requirements:



 


SIEVE SIZE Percent Passing




Grad No.

No. 50

 

No. 200



CA-7
 
 
 
 
100
 
95±5
 
 
45±15
 
 
5±5
 
 
 



 



   (D)   Installation requirements.



      (1)   Sewer system design and construction shall in all
respects be in accordance with the regulations of the Environmental
Protection Agency of the State of Illinois.  No construction shall commence
until a copy of a permit from this agency is filed with the village.



      (2)   The installation of sanitary sewer and appurtenances
shall conform to the requirements of this section and the following:



         (a)   PVC pipe and fittings:  ASTM D-2321.



         (b)   Reinforced concrete pipe:  Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois.



         (c)   ABS composite pipe and fittings:  ASTM D-2321.



         (d)   Ductile iron pipe and fittings :  AWWA C-600.



      (3)   Notification.  Prior to beginning the sanitary sewer
installation, the contractor shall give the Village Engineer 48 hours notice
of his or her intended time of starting work.



      (4)   Excavation.



         (a)   The width of trench, at and below the top of pipe,
shall not exceed the widths given in Section 20-2.03 of the Standard
Specifications.



         (b)   The trench shall be excavated so that a minimum of
six inches of CA-7 can be placed as bedding material below the pipe.



         (c)   Where a firm foundation is not found to exist for
the bottom of the trench at the required depth due to soft, spongy or other
unsuitable soil, such unsuitable soil shall be removed for the full width of
the trench, and replaced with well compacted CA-7 material, or an equal
substitute if such compacted material proves unsatisfactory. 



         (d)   Where rock in either ledge or boulder formation is
encountered, it shall be removed below grade, and replaced with a
well-compacted cushion of CA-7 material having a thickness under the pipe of
not less than eight inches.



      (5)   The contractor shall be responsible for providing a
competent individual on site during all trenching operations to insure that
all OSHA and other applicable safety standards are met by construction means
and methods.



      (6)   Pipe bedding. 



         (a)   Six inches of CA-7 material shall be used as
bedding under the pipe.



         (b)   The bedding stone shall be graded along the entire
length of pipe to provide full bearing.



         (c)   The bedding stone shall extend to the spring line
of the pipe.



      (7)   Pipe cover. 



         (a)   CA-7 shall be used as cover material for the
pipe. 



         (b)   The cover material shall extend from the spring
line to six inches above the top of the pipe.



      (8)   Backfilling. 



         (a)   Backfilling of the trench shall be accomplished by
careful replacement of the excavated material after the pipe, bedding, and
cover material have been installed.



         (b)   Any pipe installed under an existing or proposed
street pavement, or within two feet of an existing or proposed pavement edge
or curb and gutter shall be backfilled to the top of the trench with CA-7
material.



      (9)   Laying. 



         (a)   The pipe shall be laid accurately to the line and
grade as designated. 



         (b)   The lubricant, mastic, or other joint material
shall be used and installed as recommended by the pipe or joint
manufacturers' specifications.



      (10)   Separation from water main.



         (a)    The sanitary sewer pipe shall be laid at least
ten feet horizontally distant from any existing or proposed water main. 



         (b)   If the sanitary sewer must cross a water main, the
top of the sewer pipe must be laid at least 18 inches below the bottom of the
water main pipe.



         (c)    If neither of these conditions can be met, other
methods of obtaining separation, as described and illustrated in the Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, shall be
followed.



      (11)   Service laterals.



         (a)   Service laterals shall consist of a tee fitting at
the sewer main, and extension of the specified service pipe to the property
line of the lot being served.



         (b)   All sewer services shall be installed in the same
manner as the sewer main.



         (c)   Where the depth of the sewer main is greater than
12 feet below the surface of the ground, a service riser shall be constructed
to an elevation of nine feet below the ground elevation, or as shown on the
plans.



         (d)   The service lateral shall slope toward the main at
the minimum rate of 1%.



         (e)   The service lateral shall be terminated at the lot
line five feet left of the center of the lot, as viewed from the street, and
plugged with a water-tight, factory-made plug.  The plug shall be backfilled
to withstand air test pressure and marked with a red 4x4 stake.



      (12)   Manhole bottoms.  Bottom fillets shall conform to
bottom half of pipe.  Where pipes enter manhole at an angle, curved flow
lines shall be formed from inlet pipe(s) to outlet pipe.



   (E)   Testing and acceptance.



      (1)   General.  All the required testing of the sanitary
sewer system shall be performed before curb and gutter or other
permanent-type surface improvement work begins.



      (2)   Cleaning.  Any pipe containing debris or sediment shall
be cleaned prior to testing and televising.



      (3)   Air test.  All sanitary sewer pipes shall be low
pressure air tested in accordance with the Standard Specifications.



      (4)   Deflection testing. 



         (a)   All flexible thermoplastic sewer main pipe shall
be deflection tested by pulling a mandrel through the pipe from manhole to
manhole. 



         (b)   Deflection testing shall be performed in
accordance with the Standard Specifications.



      (5)   Televising. 



         (a)   All sanitary sewer mains shall be televised one
year after sewer installation. 



         (b)   A written report and videotape copy of the
televised main shall be provided to the village.



      (6)   Defects. 



         (a)   Any piping with dips, cracks, improperly sealed
joints, or variations from the approved grades and alignment shall be
repaired by removing and replacing the involved sections of pipe. 



         (b)   The repaired section of pipe shall then be
re-tested. 



         (c)   The village may also request other types of
testing on the sanitary sewer installation as a condition of initial
acceptance.



      (7)   Record drawings. 



         (a)   Prior to final acceptance of work, "record"
drawings shall be submitted to the village.



         (b)   One mylar reproducible and two blueline copies
shall be submitted, along with an electronic copy, in accordance with current
village requirements.



(Ord. 864, passed 11-6-95; Am. Ord. 1233, passed 5-20-02)









 



NOTES:




   1.   Manhole frame and lid shall have machined bearing surfaces. 
Sanitary manholes shall have self-sealing lids.





   2.   Maximum of two adjusting rings totaling no more than six inches
shall be used.





   3.   Sanitary manholes shall have a vertical top edge on the cone
designed to accept a chimney seal.




 


DRAWING SANITARY 1

 

TYPICAL MANHOLE TYPE A (FOR SANITARY AND STORM SEWER MANHOLES)




 



APPENDIX F:  STORM SEWER MATERIAL STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS



   (A)   General.



      (1)   All developments shall include provisions for the
construction of storm sewers and appurtenances designed in accordance with
this appendix.



      (2)   Storm sewer systems shall be installed in accordance
with the latest edition of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction in Illinois, and the latest edition of the Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, unless
otherwise modified in this appendix.



      (3)   Specification references made herein for manufactured
items, such as pipe, fittings, and manholes refer to designations of the
American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM), the American Water Works
Association (AWWA) or the American National Standards Institute (ANSI).



   (B)   Basic design standards.



      (1)   All storm sewers, streams, or channels shall be designed
to accommodate all areas that naturally flow to the area of the development
and also any additional areas, which are planned to contribute to the
drainage area as identified by the Village Engineer.



         (a)   Stormwater system design and detention shall be in
accordance with the Village of Channahon Storm Water Detention Ordinance No.
672, and subsequent amendments. 



         (b)   A minimum velocity of three feet per second shall
be maintained in pipes flowing full, in accordance with the guidelines
contained in the Illinois Department of Transportation's Drainage Manual.



         (c)   Drainage calculations shall be submitted with the
development plans.



      (2)   The stormwater drainage system shall be separate and
independent of the sanitary sewer system.



      (3)   Minimum sewer size.  Storm sewer serving inlets shall
not be less than 12-inch diameter.



      (4)   Alignment.  Sewer shall be laid straight in both
horizontal and vertical planes between manholes.



      (5)   Sewer size changes. 



         (a)   Storm sewers of different diameters shall join
only at structures. 



         (b)   The invert elevations shall be adjusted to
maintain a uniform energy gradient by matching the 0.8 depth points of the
different diameter.



      (6)   Stormwater inlets.



         (a)   Surface drainage inlets shall be provided so that
surface water is not carried across any street intersections or parking lot
drives. 



               1.   Surface runoff shall not extend a
distance of more than 400 feet along the surface of the ground, and shall not
build up a flow of more than two cubic feet per second in a ten-year storm
before being intercepted by drainage inlets. 



               2.   Inlets shall discharge into storm
sewers, which shall not discharge into side lot or rear lot drainage
ditches. 



               3.   Inlets shall be provided at all low
points.



         (b)   Size.  Inlets shall have 24-inch inside diameter.



         (c)   Adjustment.



               1.    At least one two-inch precast concrete
adjusting ring shall be used on each inlet barrel to provide a base for the
frame and grate. 



               2.   No more than two precast concrete
adjusting rings, with six-inch maximum height adjustment, will be allowed.



         (d)   Rear yard inlets having a minimum depth of two
feet shall be provided where necessary.



      (7)   Lot drainage.



         (a)   Positive drainage shall be established for each
lot, whether or not it is the intention to construct a building on that lot. 



         (b)   Sump pump connections shall be required in all
areas where storm sewer service tees are available.



      (8)   Catch basins.



         (a)   Catch basins shall be located where required to
catch debris that may enter through inlet grates before it is introduced into
the main storm sewer piping system.



         (b)   Type C catch basins shall be used for catch basins
no deeper than four feet.



         (c)   Type A catch basins shall be used for all catch
basins over four feet deep or if pipe size and configuration prohibits the
use of a Type C basin.



      (9)   Storm sewer manholes.



         (a)   Manholes shall be located as follows:



               1.   At the termination of all sewers which
do not terminate at a catch basin or inlet;



               2.   Changes in direction, horizontal or
vertical;



               3.   Changes in shape or pipe size; and



               4.   Junctions with other storm sewers.



         (b)   Access spacing shall be:



 


STORM SEWER PIPE SIZE (in inches)

 

MAXIMUM MANHOLE INTERVAL (in feet)




12 - 24

 

350




27 - 36

 

400




42 or larger

 

500




 



         (c)   Where flows, pipe size, or other conditions
dictate, special manholes or junction chambers shall be designed and
constructed.



         (d)   Manhole size. 



               1.   Manhole size shall be as required to
accommodate the intersecting sewer pipes. 



               2.   The following table contains the
minimum design sizes:



 


SEWER PIPE IN SIZE
(in inches)

 

MANHOLE DIAMETER
(in inches)




18 or less

 

48




21 - 36

 

60




For sewers greater than 36-inch inside diameter, manhole shall have an offset
riser pipe of 48-inch inside diameter.




 



         (e)   Adjustment.  No more than two precast concrete
adjusting rings, with six-inch maximum height adjustment, shall be allowed.



      (10)   Sewer depth.  Storm sewers shall be constructed
sufficiently deep so as to prevent freezing and to provide an outfall for all
stormwater  within the ultimate service area, both existing and future.



      (11)   Sewer pipe class.  Sewer pipe class shall be
determined based upon the latest edition of the Standard Specifications for
Road and Bridge Construction.



      (12)   All pipes shall be terminated with precast, reinforced
flared end sections.



   (C)   Material specifications. All storm sewer system elements shall
conform to the following specifications:



      (1)   Sewer pipe.



         (a)   Reinforced concrete pipe (12-inch diameter and
larger):  circular reinforcement, minimum Class 3, wall B, ASTM C-76.



         (b)   Non-reinforced concrete sewer pipe: minimum Class
3, ASTM C-14.



         (c)   Reinforced concrete, elliptical culvert pipe: 
minimum Class HE-III or VE-III, ASTM C-507.



         (d)   Galvanized corrugated steel culvert pipe:  AASHTO
M246, Type B, minimum wall thickness 14 gauge.  (Shall only be used for
culverts upon village approval.)



         (e)   Reinforced concrete, arch culvert pipe: 
double-line reinforcement, minimum Class 3, ASTM C-507.



         (f)   High density polyethylene (HDPE) pipe may be
utilized for sump pump discharge conveyance systems when in conformance with
all applicable ASTM and AASHTO standards.



      (2)   Sewer pipe joints.



         (a)   Reinforced concrete pipe:  ASTM C-443 or ASTM
C-361 ("O" ring).



         (b)   Reinforced arch or elliptical pipe:  ASTM C-877.



      (3)   Casing pipes.  Steel pipe:  ASTM A-120, 3/8-inch
minimum thickness.



      (4)   Manholes and catch basins.



         (a)   Precast reinforced concrete:  ASTM C-478.



         (b)   Manhole bases shall be precast.



         (c)   Joints. 



            1.   Storm sewer manhole joints shall be sealed
with O-ring gaskets or mastic material.



            2.   Storm sewer pipe connections to manholes
shall be mortared.



         (d)   Steps.  Sixteen inches on center, cast in place,
E.J.I.W. No. 8518, or steel-reinforced plastic conforming to OSHA standards.



         (e)   A negative pressure vacuum test shall be required
for all sanitary manholes in accordance with ASTM C-1244-93 standard.



      (5)   Inlets.  Precast reinforced concrete:  ASTM C-478.



      (6)   Castings.



         (a)   Manhole frame and cover:  E.J.I.W. No. 1020,
embossed "STORM" and "VILLAGE OF CHANNAHON" with Type A heavy duty cover.



         (b)   Six-inch curb and gutter inlet:  E.J.I.W. No.
7210, with Type M1 grate.



         (c)   Rolled curb and gutter inlet:  E.J.I.W. No. 7525.



         (d)   Depressed curb and gutter:  E.J.I.W. No. 7210,
with Type M3 grate.



         (e)   Yard inlet:  E.J.I.W. No. 1020, with Type M2 flat
grate or Type 01 Beehive or Type 2 Beehive as approved during final
engineering review.



      (7)   Bedding stone and trench backfill.  IDOT gradation CA-7
crushed stone or crushed gravel meeting the following gradation requirements:



 


SIEVE SIZE Percent Passing

   (D)   Installation.



      (1)   Notification.  Prior to beginning the storm sewer
installation, the contractor shall give the Village Engineer 48 hours notice
of his or her intended time of starting work.



      (2)   Erosion control. 



         (a)   All soil erosion control measures are to be in
place prior to and during the installation of the stormwater piping and
detention system. 



         (b)   The soil erosion measures shall be in accordance
with the Procedures and Standards for Urban Soil Erosion Control in Illinois,
the General National Pollution Discharge Elimination (NPDES) Permit, the
project plans and specifications, or as directed by the Engineer or village.



      (3)   Excavation.



         (a)   The width of trench, at and below the top of pipe,
shall not exceed the widths given in Section 20-2.03 of the Standard
Specifications.



         (b)   The trench shall be excavated so that a minimum of
six inches of CA-7 can be placed as bedding material.



         (c)   Where a firm foundation is not found to exist for
the bottom of the trench at the required depth due to soft, spongy or other
unsuitable soil, such unsuitable soil shall be removed for the full width of
the trench, and replaced with well-compacted CA-7 material, or an equal
substitute if such compacted material proves unsatisfactory. 



         (d)   Where rock in either ledge or boulder formation is
encountered, it shall be removed below grade, and replaced with a
well-compacted cushion of CA-7 material having a thickness under the pipe of
not less than eight inches.



      (4)   The contractor shall be responsible for providing a
competent individual on site during all trenching operations to insure that
all OSHA and other applicable safety standards are met by construction means
and methods.



      (5)   Pipe bedding. 



         (a)   Six inches of CA-7 material shall be used as
bedding under the pipe. 



         (b)   The bedding stone shall be graded along the entire
length of pipe to provide full bearing.



         (c)   The bedding stone shall extend to the springline
of the pipe.



      (6)   Backfilling. 



         (a)   Backfilling of the trench shall be accomplished by
careful replacement of the excavated material after the pipe and the bedding
material have been installed. 



         (b)   Any pipe installed under an existing or proposed
street pavement, or within two feet of an existing or proposed pavement edge
or curb and gutter shall be backfilled to the top of the trench with CA-7
material.



      (7)   Laying. 



         (a)   The pipe shall be laid accurately to the line and
grade as designated. 



         (b)   The lubricant, mastic, or other joint material
shall be used and installed as recommended by the pipe or joint
manufacturers' specifications.



      (8)   Separation from water main.



         (a)   The storm sewer pipe shall be laid at least ten
feet horizontally distant from any existing or proposed water main. 



         (b)   If the storm sewer must cross a water main, the
top of the storm sewer pipe must be laid at least 18 inches below the bottom
of the water main pipe. 



         (c)   If neither of these conditions can be met, other
methods of obtaining separation, as described and illustrated in the Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, shall be
followed.



   (E)   Testing and acceptance.



      (1)   General.  All the required testing and correction of
defects of the storm sewer system shall be performed before curb and gutter
or other permanent-type surface improvement work begins.



      (2)   Cleaning.  Any pipes or manholes containing debris or
sediment shall be cleaned prior to acceptance.



      (3)   Defects.



         (a)   Any piping with cracks, improperly sealed joints,
or variations from the approved grades and alignment shall be repaired by
removing and replacing the involved sections of pipe.



         (b)   The Village Engineer may require compaction,
leakage, or other types of testing as a condition of the storm sewer system
initial acceptance.



      (4)   Drawings.



         (a)   Record drawings prior to final acceptance of work,
"record" drawings shall be submitted to the village. 



         (b)   One mylar reproducible and two blueline copies
shall be submitted, along with an electronic copy, in accordance with the
current village requirements.



(Ord. 864, passed 11-6-95; Am. Ord. 1233, passed 5-20-02; Am. Ord. 1589,
passed 8-3-09)

   2.   Maximum of two adjusting rings totaling no more than six inches
shall be used.



   3.   Sanitary manholes shall have a vertical top edge on the cone
designed to accept a chimney seal.

APPENDIX G:  WATER SUPPLY MATERIAL STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS



   (A)   General.



      (1)   All development shall include provisions for the
construction of water distribution facilities complete with valves, fire
hydrants, and other such appurtenances designed in accordance with this
appendix.



         (a)   As a minimum, the water distribution system shall
provide a service connection(s) near the front property line of each
individual lot or parcel within the development. 



         (b)   Where more than one building is located or planned
on one lot or parcel of property for fire protection, the proposed
construction shall also include all water main construction and appurtenances
within the lot or parcel except service lines.



      (2)   Water distribution systems shall be constructed in
accordance with the latest edition of the Standard Specifications for Water
and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, and the latest edition of the
Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction in Illinois, unless
otherwise modified in this appendix.



      (3)   Specification references made herein for manufactured
materials, such as pipe, hydrants, valves, and fittings refer to designations
of the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM), the American Water
Works Association (AWWA) or the American National Standards Institute (ANSI).



   (B)   Basic design standards.



      (1)   System extension.



         (a)   Extension to the water distribution system shall
form a complete network extension, or part of a complete network extension
that includes all primary mains, secondary mains, and gridiron mains,
complimenting the existing distribution system network.



         (b)   Primary mains are those that form the arterial
portion of the system. 



            1.   Primary mains under construction within a
development are further defined as mains that are 16 inches or larger.



            2.   Secondary mains shall be sized, looped, and
spaced as required for fire flows and shall have a minimum diameter of eight
inches.



         (c)   Gridiron mains shall form a grid to supply water
to the local fire hydrants and service lines.



            1.   Gridiron mains shall have a minimum diameter
of eight inches. 



            2.   Dead ends shall be avoided whenever possible,
and shall not exceed 600 feet.



         (d)   The maximum number of valves to be operated for a
shut down shall be three; four may be allowed in unique cases with the
approval of the village.



      (2)   Maximum day consumption.



         (a)   For purposes of water main design, maximum day
consumption for water main design shall be based on the following table:



 


TYPE OF ESTABLISHMENT

 

UNIT

 

MAXIMUM DAY CONSUMPTION* Gal/Day/Unit






Retail ( >100,000 sq. feet)

 

Employee (one shift)

 
   105



Retail ( <100,000 sq. feet)

 

Employee (one shift)

 
   65



Office

 

Person (one shift)

 
   50



Industrial

 

Person (one shift)

 
   75



Restaurant

 

Meal served

 
   15


Theater
 
Per seat
 
   10


Hotel
 
Per guest
 
   210



* Quantities are exclusive of process water requirements which must be
estimated and added.





 



         (b)   For other than residential developments, when the
details of the development are not known, the maximum day consumption and
fire flow may be estimated by the Village Engineer. 



         (c)   Such estimate shall not relieve the owner or
developer of the responsibility of providing adequate main capacity for any
and all future needs within the development.



      (3)   Head losses. 



         (a)   Head losses due to friction shall be computed
using the Hazen-Williams formula with a "C" factor no greater than 100. 



         (b)   Head loss calculations shall be submitted to the
village for approval.



      (4)   Main capacity.  Primary mains, secondary mains, and
gridiron mains shall be sized to provide sufficient capacity to deliver the
required fire flow plus the consumption at the maximum daily rate to all
areas served by the proposed construction.



      (5)   Required fire flow and pressure. 



         (a)   A separate fire flow report shall be prepared that
indicates that at selected locations, and at any other locations that may be
selected by the village or the Village Engineer, the fire flows required, in
excess of maximum daily consumptive demands, will be supplied using a "C"
factor of 100, ignoring fittings, and with a minimum residual hydrant
pressure of 20 psi. 



         (b)   Required fire flow shall be computed as detailed
in the latest edition of the Guide for Determination of Required Fire Flow ,
published by the Insurance Service Office. 



         (c)   The developer's engineer shall furnish any
necessary design calculations to ensure that all water mains are sized to
provide ISO fire protection flow rates or the rates shown in the following
table, whichever is higher:



 

Single-Family Residential
 
   1,500 GPM @25 psi


Multifamily Residential
 
   2,500 GPM @25 psi


Commercial-Industrial
 
   3,500 GPM @25 psi



 



      (6)   Fire hydrant spacing.



         (a)   The maximum distance between fire hydrants shall
be 350 feet. 



               1.   Fire hydrants shall be provided so as
to provide the required fire flows to structures as described in the latest
edition of the Fire Suppressions Rating Schedule, published by the Insurance
Service Office.



               2.    Six-inch main extensions serving
hydrants shall not be more than 100-feet long. 



         (b)   Placement on private property.



               1.   Fire hydrants shall be placed on
private property when the Fire Chief of the Fire District determines that
fire hydrants are at too great a distance to provide proper protection for
multifamily, commercial, or industrial properties. 



               2.   Easements shall be provided for all
hydrants on private property.



      (7)   Valve spacing. 



         (a)   A sufficient number of valves shall be provided so
that a break or other failure will not affect more than 32 residential units
or 1,000 feet of main in nonresidential areas. 



         (b)   All valves six inches and larger must be installed
in valve vaults (fire hydrant auxiliary exempted).



   (C)   Material specifications and details.  All water distribution
system elements shall conform to the following specifications:



      (1)   Ductile iron pipe.



         (a)   Pipe class thickness:  Class 52, minimum
thickness per AWWA C-151, or as required by AWWA C-150 for various depths.



         (b)   Joints:  push-on and mechanical, AWWA C-111.



         (c)   Polyvinyl wrap:  AWWA C-105.



         (d)   Fittings:  cast or ductile iron, AWWA C-110 and
AWWA C-111.



      (2)   Valves.



         (a)   Twelve-inch and smaller: epoxy-coated resilient
wedge, with non-rising stem gate valves, counter-clockwise to open, AWWA
C-509.



         (b)   Fourteen-inch and larger: epoxy-coated iron body,
rubber seat, butterfly valve, counter-clockwise to open, AWWA C-504.



         (c)   Joint end:  mechanical.



      (3)   Fire hydrants.



         (a)   Mueller Super Centurion 250 or Clow Medallion,
factory primed with Sherwin Williams Pro Industrial acrylic off-white
Pro-Cryl primer and factory painted with Sherwin Williams Safety Yellow Aqua
400 with UV Absorbers, FEDERAL STD. COLOR 595B NO. 13591. A protective top
coat as recommended by the manufacturer shall be factory applied.



         (b)   Valve size:  51/4-inch, counter-clockwise to open.



         (c)   Nozzles:  two at 21/2-inch, one at 41/2-inch,
with threads conforming to National Standard Specifications.



         (d)   Breakaway type with the break-line flanges located
one inch above finished grade.



         (e)   Hydrant to be installed with MJ swivel Tee, with
swivel MJ Gland.



         (f)   Auxiliary valve to be flanged attachment to the
fire hydrant, and to be of the same manufacture as the fire hydrant.



      (4)   Hydrant valve box.



         (a)   Tyler 664-S.



         (b)   Lid embossed "WATER".



         (c)   Stabilizer for box shall be used.



      (5)   Corporation stops:  Mueller H-15000, one-inch minimum.



      (6)   Service pipe.



         (a)   Copper tube.



               1.   Two-inch and smaller; Type K (one-inch
minimum). 



               2.   Continuous from corporation stop to
curb stop, and from curb stop to inside building.



               3.   Exceptions only approved by the village
or the Village Engineer.



         (b)   Ductile iron:  larger than two-inch.



      (7)   Curb stop.



         (a)   Copper service:  Mueller H-15154.



         (b)   Ductile iron service:  conform to subsections
(C)(2)(a) and (C)(2)(c) above.



      (8)   Curb box.



         (a)   Copper service:  Mueller H-10302 or H-10304.



         (b)   Ductile iron service:  four-inch and smaller,
conform to subsection (C)(4) above.



         (c)   Ductile iron service:  six-inch and larger,
conform to subsection (C)(11) below.



      (9)   Thrust restraints.



         (a)   Horizontal reactions: thrust restraints at all
tees, plugged ends, hydrants, and bends between 111/4 degrees and 90 degrees.



         (b)   Vertical reactions: individual designs for each
location shall be submitted with the development plans.



         (c)   Material:  precast or poured concrete.



         (d)   Where undisturbed earth is not available or not
likely to be available to back up pressure-type concrete thrust blocks, the
development plans shall specify Megalug retainer glands or tie rods, with or
without anchor-type thrust blocks. 



               1.   Design data shall be submitted for such
specifications. 



               2.   Care shall be taken when pouring
concrete so that the mix will not interfere with access to joints or with
hydrant drainage.



      (10)   Casing pipes.  Steel pipe ASTM A-120, 0.375-inch
minimum thickness.



      (11)   Valve vaults.



         (a)   Precast reinforced concrete:  ASTM C-478.



         (b)   Size.



               1.   For six-, eight-, ten-, and
12-inch-diameter valves, valve vaults shall have a 48-inch inside diameter.



               2.   For pressure connections and valves
16-inch and larger, valve vaults shall have a 60-inch inside diameter.



         (c)   Adjustment:  No more than two precast concrete
adjusting rings, with six-inch maximum total height adjustment, shall be
allowed.



         (d)   Valve vaults requiring offset cones shall be
positioned so that neither the inside of the cone nor the manhole steps will
interfere with the operation of the valve.



      (12)   Castings.



         (a)   Manhole frame and cover:  East Jordan Iron Works,
Inc. (E.J.I.W.) 1020 and 1020A HD, embossed "WATER" and "VILLAGE OF
CHANNAHON".



         (b)   Manhole steps:  E.J.I.W. 8518 or steel-reinforced
plastic, conforming to OSHA standards, 16 inches on center.



      (13)   Pipe bedding cover and trench backfill.  IDOT
gradation CA-7 crushed stone or crushed gravel meeting the following
gradation requirements:



 


SIEVE SIZE

   (D)   Installation requirements.



      (1)   Environmental Protection Agency permit. 



         (a)   Water system design and construction shall, in all
respects, be in accordance with the regulations of the State Environmental
Protection Agency. 



         (b)   No construction shall commence until a copy of a
permit from this agency is filed with the village and Village Engineer.



      (2)   Installation.  The installation of water mains and
appurtenances, including services, shall conform to the requirements of this
appendix and, in particular,  to AWWA C-600.



      (3)   Notification.  Prior to beginning the water main
installation, the contractor shall give the village 48 hours notice of his or
her intended time of starting work.



   (E)   Water service line:  installation and location. 



      (1)   A water service line is a water pipe connected at the
water main by a brass corporation stop or a ductile iron fitting. 



      (2)   Such pipe is extended horizontally, at right angles with
the water main, to the front line of the lot or single building that it is to
serve. 



      (3)   For all service taps larger than one inch, a service
saddle designed for the size and type of water main pipe shall be used. 



      (4)   A cast iron curb box shall be installed over curb stops
or four-inch and smaller gate valves. 



      (5)   A valve vault shall be provided for gag valves larger
than four inches. 



      (6)   The water service line shall be terminated with a brass
curb stop or gate valve six and one-half feet from the lot line, and five
feet right of the center of the lot as viewed from the street.



      (7)   The end of the service line shall be marked with a
wooden four-inch-by-four-inch stake painted blue.



   (F)   Fire service line.  All fire sprinklers shall be connected to
the water system through a separate fire service line constructed in
accordance with the requirements of this appendix.



   (G)   Separation from sewers. 



      (1)   The water main pipe shall be laid at least ten feet
horizontally distant from any existing or proposed sewer pipe. 



      (2)   If the water main must cross a sewer pipe, the bottom of
the water main pipe must be laid at least 18 inches above the top of the
sewer pipe.



      (3)   If neither of these conditions can be met, other methods
of obtaining separation, as described and illustrated in the Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, shall be
followed.



   (H)   Construction requirements.



      (1)   Excavation.



         (a)   The trench shall be excavated so that the water
main shall have a minimum of five feet of cover. 



         (b)   The trench for the pipe shall be excavated at
least 12 inches wider than the external diameter of the pipe.



         (c)   The trench shall be excavated so that a minimum of
six inches of CA-7 stone be placed as bedding material. 



         (d)   The pipe shall then be covered with a minimum of
six inches of the same stone.



         (e)   Where a firm foundation is not found to exist for
the bottom of the trench at the required depth due to soft, spongy or other
unsuitable soil, such unsuitable soil shall be removed for the full width of
the trench, and replaced with well-compacted CA-7 material, or an equal
substitute if such compacted material proves unsatisfactory. 



         (f)   Where rock in either ledge or boulder formation is
encountered, it shall be removed below grade, and replaced with a
well-compacted cushion of CA-7 material having a thickness under the pipe of
not less than eight inches.



      (2)   The contractor shall be responsible for providing a
competent individual on site during all trenching operations to insure that
all OSHA and other applicable safety standards are met by construction means
and methods.



      (3)   Laying water main.



         (a)   The contractor shall keep the trench free from
water, while the water main is being placed and the pipe joint is being
sealed to the satisfaction of the Village Engineer.



         (b)   Adequate provision shall be made for the safety,
storage and protection of all water pipe prior to actual installation in the
trench. 



            1.   Care shall be taken to prevent damage to the
pipe castings, both inside and out.



            2.   Provisions shall be made to keep the inside
of the pipe clean throughout its storage period and to keep mud and other
debris from being deposited therein. 



            3.   All pipe shall be thoroughly cleaned on the
inside before laying of the pipe. 



            4.   Proper equipment shall be used for the safe
handling, conveying, and laying of the pipe. 



            5.   All pipe shall be carefully lowered into the
trench, piece by piece, in such manner as to prevent damage to water main
materials and protective coatings and linings. 



            6.   Under no circumstances shall water main
materials be dropped or dumped into the trench.



         (c)   In making joints, all portions of the joining
materials and the socket and spigot ends of the joining pipe shall be wiped
clean of all foreign materials. 



            1.   The actual assembly of the jointing shall be
in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions and as
directed by the Village Engineer. 



            2.   During construction, until jointing
operations are complete, the open ends of all pipes shall be at all times
protected and sealed with temporary watertight plugs.



         (d)   Poly-wrapping of all water mains is required,
unless soils are documented to be non-corrosive.



      (4)   Pipe cutting.



         (a)   The cutting of pipe for inserting valves,
fittings, or closure pieces shall be done in a neat and workmanlike manner,
without damage to the cement lining, and so as to leave a smooth end at right
angles to the axis of the pipe.



         (b)   Flame cutting of pipe by means of an oxyacetylene
torch shall not be allowed.



      (5)   Trench.



         (a)   The trench bottom shall be flat and shall provide
full bearing of the length of the pipe.



         (b)   Thrust blacks shall be used to prevent movement at
all tees, caps, valves, and hydrants.



         (c)   Backfilling of the trench shall be accomplished by
careful replacement of the excavated material after the pipe and the bedding
material have been installed. 



         (d)   Any pipe installed under an existing or proposed
street pavement, or within two feet of an existing or proposed pavement edge
or curb and gutter, shall be backfilled to the top of the trench with CA-7
material.



      (6)   Fire hydrant.



         (a)   Fire hydrants shall be placed as specified
herein. 



            1.   There shall be no obstructions within four
feet of the fire hydrant. 



            2.   All nozzles shall stand plumb, with the
steamer nozzle pointing normal to the road.



            3.   They shall conform to the established grade,
with nozzles at 18 inches above the finished grade.



         (b)   A drainage pit two feet in diameter shall be
excavated around each hydrant, and filled completely with 3/4-inch washed
gravel under and around the bowl of the drain opening. 



         (c)   No hydrant drainage pit shall be connected to a
sewer.



         (d)   Hydrant leads and extensions shall be provided, as
needed, in order to maintain adequate setback from the curb, and to provide
the proper distance from the hydrant nozzles to the final grade elevation.



      (7)   Water main installation. 



         (a)   During water main installation, to make a closure
between two pipe ends, or between pipe end fittings, or between pipe end and
valve, short lengths shall be used with proper connections or couplings.



         (b)   Repair sleeves shall not be used to make closures
during new construction.



      (8)   Dewatering. 



         (a)   Where water is encountered in the trench, it shall
be removed during pipe-laying and jointing operations. 



         (b)   Trench water shall not be allowed to enter the
pipe at any time.



      (9)   Connections to existing mains.  All connections to the
village water distribution system shall be made under full water service
pressure, unless otherwise approved by the Village Engineer at locations
approved by the Village Engineer.



   (I)   Pressure test.



      (1)   As part of the construction, the water mains shall be
pressure tested in accordance with this appendix. 



         (a)   All testing shall be performed before curb and
gutter or other permanent-type surface improvement work begins. 



         (b)   The Director of Public Works and Village Engineer
shall be notified at least 24 hours before the test. 



         (c)   The filling of the water main shall be at a rate
set by the village, with all hydrants and whips in the open position, and
slowly closed in the order in which water appears. 



         (d)   A form documenting the test procedure and results
shall be signed by the contractor and the representative for the village
witnessing the test.



      (2)   All newly laid pipe shall be subjected to a hydrostatic
pressure of 150 pounds per square inch, in accordance with the latest edition
of AWWA Standard C-600-93, Section 4: Hydrostatic Teting. 



         (a)   Allowable leakage, measured in gph (gallons per
hour) per 1,000 feet of pipeline, as specified in Table 6A of AWWA Standard
C-600-93, shall apply.



         (b)   Duration of each pressure test shall be for a
period of not less than two hours.



         (c)   Each valved section of pipe shall be filled with
water and the specified test pressure shall be applied by means of a pump
connected to the pipe. 



         (d)   Before applying the specified test pressure, all
air shall be expelled from the pipe. 



         (e)   All leaks shall be repaired until tight. 



         (f)   Any cracked or defective pipes, fittings, valves
or hydrants discovered in consequence of this pressure test shall be removed,
and replaced and the test repeated until satisfactory results are obtained.



      (3)   All testing shall be done before the installation of
service lines.



   (J)   Preliminary flushing. 



      (1)   Prior to chlorination, the main shall be flushed as
thoroughly as possible with the water pressure and outlets available. 



      (2)   The Superintendent of Public Works shall be notified
before any water is drawn from village mains. 



      (3)   Flushing shall be done after the pressure test is made. 



      (4)   Because such flushing removes only the lighter solids,
it cannot be relied upon to remove heavy material allowed to get into the
main during laying. 



      (5)   If no hydrant is installed at the end of the main, a tap
should be provided large enough to effect a velocity in the main of at least
two and one-half feet per second.



   (K)   Disinfection.



      (1)   Application of chlorinating agent.



         (a)   The preferred point of application of the
chlorinating agent shall be at the beginning of the pipeline extension, or
any valved section of it, and through a corporation stop in the top of the
newly laid pipe.



         (b)   The injector for delivering the chlorine gas into
the pipe should be supplied from a tap on the pressure side of the gate valve
controlling the flow into the pipeline extension.



      (2)   Flow of water.  Water from the existing distribution
system or any other source of supply shall be controlled so as to flow slowly
into the newly laid pipeline during the application of chlorine gas. 



         (a)   The rate of chlorine mixture flow shall be in such
proportion to the rate of water entering the pipe that the chlorine dose
applied to the water entering the newly laid pipe shall be at least 50 ppm,
or enough to meet the requirements during the retention period. 



         (b)   This may require as much as 100 ppm of chlorine in
the water left in the line after chlorination.



      (3)   Flow of chlorinating agent.



         (a)   Valves shall be manipulated so that the strong
chlorine solution in the line being treated shall not flow back into the line
supplying the water. 



         (b)   The pipe section being chlorinated shall be kept
at a lower pressure than the water system pressure.



      (4)   Retention of treated water.  Treated water shall be
retained in the pipe long enough to destroy all spore-forming bacteria.



         (a)   This retention period shall be at least 24 hours. 



         (b)   After the chlorine-treated water has been retained
for the required time, the chlorine residual at the pipe extremities and at
other representative points shall be at least 10 ppm.



      (5)   In the process of chlorinating newly laid pipe, all
valves or other appurtenances shall be operated while the pipeline is filled
with the chlorinating agent.



      (6)   All water mains shall be disinfected and tested
according to the requirements of the Standards for Disinfecting Water Mains,
AWWA C-601, as amended from time to time, and as required by this appendix. 



         (a)   All disinfection, as required by this appendix,
shall be performed by an independent firm exhibiting experience in the
methods and techniques of this operation, and shall be approved by the
village.



         (b)   Village personnel must be present during any
chlorination.



      (7)   Disinfection shall be done by the continuous-feed method.



      (8)   Installation of permanent fittings.



         (a)   All building service lines (four inches in
diameter or larger) shall be chlorinated/disinfected only after permanent
fittings have been installed. 



         (b)   Removal of any such fitting may require the
service line to be re-sampled or re-chlorinated at the discretion of the
village.



   (L)   Final flushing and testing.



      (1)   Following chlorination, all treated water shall be
thoroughly flushed from the newly laid pipeline at its extremities until the
replacement water, throughout its length shall, upon test, be approved as
safe water by the Village Engineer. 



         (a)   This quality of water delivered by the new main
should continue for a period of at least two full days, as demonstrated by
laboratory examination of samples taken from a tap located and installed in
such a way as to prevent outside contamination. 



         (b)   Samples should never be taken from an unsterilized
hose or from a fire hydrant because such samples seldom meet current
bacteriological standards.



      (2)   After disinfecting and flushing, a minimum of two water
samples shall be collected by the contractor on two successive days, with
notice given, so that the collection may be witnessed by the village.



         (a)   Bacteriological sampling and analysis of the
samples shall be performed by a laboratory approved by the State Department
of Public Health and the village. 



         (b)   Should the initial treatment result in an
unsatisfactory bacteriological test, the procedure shall be repeated until
satisfactory results are obtained. 



         (c)   The contractor or developer shall pay for the
sampling and analysis. 



         (d)   Results shall be transmitted by the laboratory
directly to the village.



         (e)   Test  results shall indicate the date the sample
was made, the exact locations at which sample were taken, the firm submitting
the sample, and the project at which the samples were collected. 



         (f)   Sufficient samples shall be collected in order to
insure that the system is bacteriologically safe.



      (3)   Village operation of valves, hydrants and other
appurtenances.



         (a)   The village shall operate the valves, hydrants and
any other appurtenances to flush the water main after the receipt of
satisfactory water samples. 



         (b)   Any operation difficulties or deficiencies shall
be noted and submitted to the developer or contractor for repair.



      (4)   All corporation stops used for testing and chlorination
purposes shall be removed and plugged with a tapered brass plug.



      (5)   Fire-flow testing will be performed by the village.



      (6)   Drawings.



         (a)   Prior to final acceptance of work, "record"
drawings shall be submitted to the village. 



         (b)   One mylar reproducible and two blueline copies
shall be submitted, along with an electronic copy, in accordance with the
current village requirements.



(Ord. 864, passed 11-6-95; Am. Ord. 1233, passed 5-20-02; Am. Ord. 1901,
passed 7-17-17)

NOTES:




   1.   Valve vault diameter shall be 48 inches for eight-inch and
smaller valves, and 60 inches for ten-inch  and larger valves or for
pressure connections.





   2.   Bituminous mastic material shall be placed between all manhole
sections and adjusting rings.





   3.   Access opening and steps shall be positioned so as not to
interfere with valve operation from above.





   4.   Maximum of two adjusting rings totaling no more than six inches
shall be used.

APPENDIX H:  CURB AND GUTTER MATERIAL STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS



   (A)   General.



      (1)   All curbs and gutters shall be installed in accordance
with the material installation and testing requirements of the latest edition
of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction in Illinois,
unless otherwise modified in this appendix.



      (2)   Specification references made herein for manufactured
items, such as reinforcement, refer to designations of the American Society
for Testing and Materials (ASTM).



   (B)   Curb standards.



      (1)   Residential.



         (a)   Rolled-type combination curb and gutter conforming
to the dimensions shown in the rolled curb and gutter detail shall be used.



         (b)   The back of curb shall be depressed at all
sidewalk handicapped ramp locations.



         (c)   Depressing rolled curb at driveways will not be
allowed.



         (d)   The back of curb shall be stamped with the letters
"W" for water and "S" for sewer, at the location where the respective service
to each lot crosses under the curb.



      (2)   Commercial/industrial.



         (a)   Vertical face barrier-type combination curb and
gutter conforming to the dimensions shown in the vertical faced curb and
gutter detail shall be used.



         (b)   Depressed curb shall be provided at all sidewalk
handicapped ramp locations, and at all driveways whose locations are known at
the time of curb installation. 



         (c)   If the driveway location is not known at the time
of curb and gutter installation, vertical face barrier curb shall be
installed, and the driveway opening will be provided later by the lot owner.



         (d)   The back of curb shall be stamped with the letters
"W" for water and "S" for sewer, at the location where the respective service
to each lot crosses under the curb.



   (C)   Material.



      (1)   Concrete. 



         (a)   Portland cement concrete having a minimum
compressive strength of 4,000 pounds per square inch in 28 days shall be
used. 



         (b)   Air entrainment shall be in the 3% to 6% range.



         (c)   Slump shall be two to four inches, except, if a
slipform paver is used, the slump shall be adjusted to meet the requirements
of the slip-forming process.



      (2)   Expansion joint filler.  Bituminous, preformed
expansion joint filler, 3/4-inch thick and pre-shaped to the profile of the
curb, shall be used.



      (3)   Expansion joint dowels.  Smooth steel dowels, 
3/4-inch diameter and 18 inches long with pinched stop caps on one end, shall
be used.



      (4)   Reinforcement bars.  Reinforcement bars shall be ASTM
A-615, minimum grade 40 steel.



      (5)   Joint sealant.  A cold-poured joint compound shall be
used.



      (6)   Curing compound.  Curing compound shall be Type II or
III, as specified in Section 722 of the Standard Specification for Road and
Bridge Construction.



      (7)   Curb base course.  Curb base course shall be IDOT
gradation CA-6 crushed stone or crushed gravel meeting the following
gradation requirements:



 


SIEVE SIZE

   (D)   Installation.



      (1)   Base preparation. 



         (a)   The base course shall be CA-6, trimmed or filled
as necessary to provide a full depth of curb and gutter, as shown in the curb
detail. 



         (b)   Prior to concrete placement, the base course shall
be compacted and proofrolled in accordance with the testing and acceptance
requirements below.



      (2)   Reinforcement.



         (a)   Two No. 4 reinforcing bars with a minimum length
of ten feet shall be placed in all rolled curbs and gutters across utility
trenches in residential areas.



         (b)    The reinforcing bars shall extend at least two
feet beyond the edges of the trench on both sides.



         (c)   Two No. 4 reinforcing bars shall be placed
continuous, between expansion joints, in all vertical-faced barrier curbs and
gutters in industrial and commercial areas.



      (3)   Placing and finishing concrete.



         (a)   Concrete shall be thoroughly tamped to remove all
voids. 



            1.   The curb and gutter surface shall be broom
finished at right angles to the flow line of the curb and gutter. 



            2.   Any honeycombed areas along the sides of the
curb shall be pointed with mortar. 



            3.   The village shall be notified at least 24
hours before pouring the curb.



         (b)   The curb shall be depressed for handicapped ramps
at all sidewalk locations.



      (4)   Curing and protection. 



         (a)   The curb shall be sealed with curing compound as
the finishing work proceeds. 



         (b)   Protection shall be in accordance with the
standard specifications.



      (5)   Joints.



         (a)   Expansion joints shall be placed, as a minimum, at
all curb radius points and all construction joints in the curb, and shall
consist of expansion-joint filler and dowels with end caps.



         (b)   Contraction joints shall be sawcut at 20-foot
maximum intervals to a depth of two inches.



            1.    Sawing shall be done as soon as practical
before any random shrinkage cracking occurs, and no later than 24 hours after
the concrete has been placed. 



            2.   The clean joint space shall be sealed with a
cold-poured joint compound.



   (E)   Testing and acceptance.



      (1)   Proofroll. 



         (a)   The curb and gutter base course shall be
proofrolled with a fully loaded dump truck before the curb and gutter is
poured. 



         (b)   The Village Engineer shall be notified at least 24
hours before proofrolling. 



         (c)   Additional proofrolls shall be provided to verify
that any unstable areas have been repaired.



      (2)   Concrete.



         (a)   Test cylinders.



            1.   In accordance with ASTM C-31, the contractor
shall make:



               a.   At least two test cylinders from each
concrete pour less than 25 cubic yards; and



               b.   At least four cylinders for each pour
of 25 yards and above.



            2.   In accordance with ASTM C-39, the contractor
shall have the cylinders tested at 28 days by an independent testing firm,
and the test results mailed directly to the village with a copy to the
Village Engineer. 



            3.   If the materials tested fail to meet any of
the requirements of the tests, the portions of the job for which the
particular test was made may be rejected.



         (b)   The village may require that the slump and air
content of the concrete also be tested. 



            1.   All costs of testing shall be borne by the
contractor. 



            2.   Any concrete not conforming to the standard
specifications will be rejected.



   (F)   Defects.  Any curb that has been installed at the improper
line and grade that is damaged or badly cracked, or that has been installed
with improper material, shall be removed and replaced as a condition of
acceptance.



(Ord. 864, passed 11-6-95; Am. Ord. 1233, passed 5-20-02)

   3.   Contraction joint spaces shall be sealed with a cold-poured
joint compound.

   5.   Concrete-curing compound shall be applied as finishing work
proceeds.

APPENDIX I:  STREET LIGHT MATERIAL STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS



   All subdivisions shall submit public improvement and development plans
that incorporate a proposed street lighting system to the village.  The
street lighting plan shall show the location and direction of the pole and
mast, and the proposed routing of the electric cable and duct.  The pole
size, bracket size and catalog numbers are to be shown on the street light
plans. An approved photometric drawing shall be supplied indicating proposed
street lighting coverage when developing individual parcels not subject to
the spacing requirements on roadways in accordance with Appendix I.



   (A)   Lighting standards.



      (1)   Residential.



         (a)   Placement at intersections of major streets.



            1.   A 250-watt-luminaire, high-pressure,
sodium-vapor, color-corrected lamp shall be placed at all intersections of
public street with township, county or state highway and major streets. 



            2.   A MAJOR STREET is defined as any street with
a right-of-way width greater than 66 feet.



         (b)   Placement at cross or “T” intersections, end
of streets and cul-de-sacs, mid-blocks and major curves.



            1.   A 150-watt-luminaire, high-pressure,
sodium-vapor, color-corrected lamp shall be placed at all cross or "T"
intersections and at the end of streets and cul-de-sacs. 



            2.   A 150-watt luminaire shall be placed at
mid-block of all blocks, at a distance not to exceed 340 feet between lamps. 



            3.   A 150-watt luminaire shall also be placed at
all major curves in street alignment.



         (c)   Mounting height shall be 25 feet for all poles,
except by approval of the village.



         (d)   All electric cable shall be placed underground in
a unit duct. 



            1.   Each light shall have a single feed from the
light standard to the point of connection to Commonwealth Edison electric
lines. 



            2.   The service disconnect shall be:  Square D
part number D221NRB, Series E2, rated 30 amp 240 V.A.C., and placed within
three feet of Commonwealth Edison's transformer or pedestal.



            3.   The service disconnect shall be mounted on a
service connection pedestal 204-38CPH, with mounting post 13 MHK72 that shall
be buried three feet below grade with post and pedestal projecting three feet
above grade.  Reference "Drawing Lighting 2" for detail of the disconnect
pedestal.



         (e)   Hand hole.



            1.   A hand hole shall be provided in each pole
base for splicing purposes. 



            2.   The hand hole shall be located on the side
opposite of traffic flow.



      (2)   Commercial.



         (a)   Placement at cross or “T” intersections, end
of streets and cul-de-sacs, mid-blocks and major curves.



            1.   A 250-watt-luminaire, high-pressure,
sodium-vapor, color-corrected lamp shall be placed at all cross or "T"
intersections and at the end of streets and cul-de-sacs.



            2.    The same type luminaire shall be placed at
mid-block of all blocks, at a distance not to exceed 500 feet between lamps;
and at all major curves in street alignment.



         (b)   Placement at intersections of major streets.  A
250-watt-luminaire, high-pressure, sodium-vapor, color-corrected lamp shall
be placed at all intersections of public street with township, county or
state highway and major street.



         (c)   Mounting height shall be 30 feet for all poles. 
The bracket arm shall be ten feet.



         (d)   All electric cable shall be placed underground in
a unit duct. 



            1.   Street lights shall be installed in series
when single feeds to a connection to Commonwealth Edison electric lines are
inaccessible.



            2.   The service disconnect shall be:  Square D
part number D221NRB, Series E2, rated 30 amp 240 V.A.C., and placed within
three feet of Commonwealth Edison's transformer or pedestal.



            3.   The service disconnect shall be mounted on a
service connection pedestal 204-38CPH, with mounting post 13 MHK72 that shall
be buried three feet below grade with post and pedestal projecting three feet
above grade.  Reference "Drawing Lighting 2" for detail of the disconnect
pedestal.



         (e)   Hand hole.



            1.   A hand hole shall be provided in each pole
base for splicing purposes. 



            2.   The hand hole shall be located on the side
opposite of traffic flow.



   (B)   Light standards and brackets.



      (1)   (a)   Residential pole.



         HAPCO Company or approved equal



         P.O. Box 547

      (3)   Luminaire. 



         (a)   The luminaire shall be the type manufactured by
General Electric, as noted below, or an equivalent type approved by the
village. 



         (b)   The luminaire shall be a 150- or 250-watt, cut-off
luminaire, in accordance with subsections (A)(1) and (A)(2) of this appendix,
with attached photo cell. 



         (c)   The high-pressure sodium bulb shall be the same
type as that manufactured by General Electric, referred to as LUCALOX, as
noted below, and shall be included with the luminaries.
